title.raw: 《項羽本紀》 Annals of Xiang Yu

meta.citation: Translation: Partial translation by Garrett M. Petersen (2025); remaining portions by Herbert J. Allen (1894)

sentences.zh: 項籍者，下相人也，字羽。

translations.text: Xiang Ji was a native of Xiaxiang, with the courtesy name Yu.

sentences.zh: 初起時，年二十四。

translations.text: When he first arose, he was twenty-four years old.

sentences.zh: 其季父項梁，梁父即楚將項燕，為秦將王翦所戮者也。

translations.text: His uncle Xiang Liang's father was the Chu general Xiang Yan, who had been executed by the Qin general Wang Jian.

sentences.zh: 項氏世世為楚將，封於項，故姓項氏。

translations.text: The Xiang clan had served as Chu generals for generations; they were enfeoffed at Xiang, hence they took Xiang as their surname.

Xiang Ji was a native of Xiaxiang, with the courtesy name Yu. When he first arose, he was twenty-four years old. His uncle Xiang Liang's father was the Chu general Xiang Yan, who had been executed by the Qin general Wang Jian. The Xiang clan had served as Chu generals for generations; they were enfeoffed at Xiang, hence they took Xiang as their surname.

sentences.zh: 項籍少時，學書不成，去學劍，又不成。

translations.text: When Xiang Ji was young, he studied writing but did not succeed; he gave it up to study the sword, but again did not succeed.

sentences.zh: 項梁怒之。

translations.text: Xiang Liang was angry with him.

sentences.zh: 籍曰：「書足以記名姓而已。

translations.text: Ji said: "Writing is sufficient merely to record names.

sentences.zh: 劍一人敵，不足學，學萬人敵。」

translations.text: The sword is for fighting one person—not worth learning. I want to learn how to fight ten thousand.

sentences.zh: 於是項梁乃教籍兵法，籍大喜，略知其意，又不肯竟學。

translations.text: Thereupon Xiang Liang taught Ji military strategy. Ji was greatly pleased and came to understand its general principles, but again was unwilling to pursue it to the end.

sentences.zh: 項梁嘗有櫟陽逮，乃請蘄獄掾曹咎書抵櫟陽獄掾司馬欣，以故事得已。

translations.text: Xiang Liang once had a warrant issued against him from Liyang, so he asked Cao Jiu, the prison clerk of Qi, to write a letter to Sima Xin, the prison clerk of Liyang; by this connection the matter was dropped.

sentences.zh: 項梁殺人，與籍避仇於吳中。

translations.text: Xiang Liang killed a man and fled with Ji to avoid vengeance in the Wu region.

sentences.zh: 吳中賢士大夫皆出項梁下。

translations.text: All the worthy officers and gentlemen of Wu were inferior to Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 每吳中有大繇役及喪，項梁常為主辦，陰以兵法部勒賓客及子弟，以是知其能。

translations.text: Whenever there was a major corvée labor or funeral in Wu, Xiang Liang always took charge of organizing it, secretly using military methods to arrange his guests and young followers; by this they knew his ability.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇帝游會稽，渡浙江，梁與籍俱觀。

translations.text: When the First Emperor of Qin traveled to Kuaiji and crossed the Zhe River, Liang and Ji both went to observe.

sentences.zh: 籍曰：「彼可取而代也。」

translations.text: Ji said: "That one can be taken and replaced!"

sentences.zh: 梁掩其口，曰：「毋妄言，族矣！」

translations.text: Liang covered his mouth and said: "Do not speak recklessly—you will bring destruction on the clan!"

sentences.zh: 梁以此奇籍。

translations.text: Liang considered Ji extraordinary for this.

sentences.zh: 籍長八尺餘，力能扛鼎，才氣過人，雖吳中子弟皆已憚籍矣。

translations.text: Ji was over eight feet tall, had strength enough to lift a tripod, and his talent and spirit surpassed others; even the young men of Wu all stood in awe of Ji.

When Xiang Ji was young, he studied writing but did not succeed; he gave it up to study the sword, but again did not succeed. Xiang Liang was angry with him. Ji said: "Writing is sufficient merely to record names. The sword is for fighting one person—not worth learning. I want to learn how to fight ten thousand. Thereupon Xiang Liang taught Ji military strategy. Ji was greatly pleased and came to understand its general principles, but again was unwilling to pursue it to the end. Xiang Liang once had a warrant issued against him from Liyang, so he asked Cao Jiu, the prison clerk of Qi, to write a letter to Sima Xin, the prison clerk of Liyang; by this connection the matter was dropped. Xiang Liang killed a man and fled with Ji to avoid vengeance in the Wu region. All the worthy officers and gentlemen of Wu were inferior to Xiang Liang. Whenever there was a major corvée labor or funeral in Wu, Xiang Liang always took charge of organizing it, secretly using military methods to arrange his guests and young followers; by this they knew his ability. When the First Emperor of Qin traveled to Kuaiji and crossed the Zhe River, Liang and Ji both went to observe. Ji said: "That one can be taken and replaced!" Liang covered his mouth and said: "Do not speak recklessly—you will bring destruction on the clan!" Liang considered Ji extraordinary for this. Ji was over eight feet tall, had strength enough to lift a tripod, and his talent and spirit surpassed others; even the young men of Wu all stood in awe of Ji.

sentences.zh: 秦二世元年七月，陳涉等起大澤中。

translations.text: In the seventh month of the first year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen She and others arose in Daze.

sentences.zh: 其九月，會稽守通謂梁曰：「江西皆反，此亦天亡秦之時也。

translations.text: That ninth month, the Commandery Administrator of Kuaiji, Tong, said to Liang: "West of the Yangtze all have rebelled; this is also the time when Heaven destroys Qin.

sentences.zh: 吾聞先即制人，後則為人所制。

translations.text: I have heard that he who acts first controls others, while he who acts later is controlled by others.

sentences.zh: 吾欲發兵，使公及桓楚將。」

translations.text: I wish to raise troops and have you and Huan Chu as generals."

sentences.zh: 是時桓楚亡在澤中。

translations.text: At that time Huan Chu was a fugitive hiding in the marshes.

sentences.zh: 梁曰：「桓楚亡，人莫知其處，獨籍知之耳。」

translations.text: Liang said: "Huan Chu is a fugitive; no one knows where he is—only Ji knows."

sentences.zh: 梁乃出，誡籍持劍居外待。

translations.text: Liang then went out and instructed Ji to hold his sword outside and wait.

sentences.zh: 梁復入，與守坐，曰：「請召籍，使受命召桓楚。」

translations.text: Liang returned inside, sat with the Administrator, and said: "Please summon Ji and have him receive orders to summon Huan Chu."

sentences.zh: 守曰：「諾。」

translations.text: The Administrator said: "Very well."

sentences.zh: 梁召籍入。

translations.text: Liang summoned Ji inside.

sentences.zh: 須臾，梁眴籍曰：「可行矣！」

translations.text: After a moment, Liang gave Ji a meaningful look and said: "It can be done now!"

sentences.zh: 於是籍遂拔劍斬守頭。

translations.text: Thereupon Ji drew his sword and beheaded the Administrator.

sentences.zh: 項梁持守頭，佩其印綬。

translations.text: Xiang Liang took the Administrator's head and donned his seal and ribbons.

sentences.zh: 門下大驚，擾亂，籍所擊殺數十百人。

translations.text: The gate attendants were greatly alarmed and in disorder; those Ji struck down numbered several tens or hundreds.

sentences.zh: 一府中皆慴伏，莫敢起。

translations.text: Everyone in the prefecture was terrified into submission; none dared rise.

sentences.zh: 梁乃召故所知豪吏，諭以所為起大事，遂舉吳中兵。

translations.text: Liang then summoned the former heroic officials he knew, explained to them why he was undertaking this great affair, and thereupon raised troops in Wu.

sentences.zh: 使人收下縣，得精兵八千人。

translations.text: He sent people to take control of subordinate counties, obtaining eight thousand crack troops.

sentences.zh: 梁部署吳中豪傑為校尉、候、司馬。

translations.text: Liang appointed the heroes of Wu as colonels, captains, and majors.

sentences.zh: 有一人不得用，自言於梁。

translations.text: There was one man who was not given appointment and spoke to Liang about it.

sentences.zh: 梁曰：「前時某喪使公主某事，不能辦，以此不任用公。」

translations.text: Liang said: "Previously at a certain funeral I had you manage a certain matter, and you could not handle it; for this reason I cannot employ you."

sentences.zh: 眾乃皆伏。

translations.text: The crowd was then all convinced.

sentences.zh: 於是梁為會稽守，籍為裨將，徇下縣。

translations.text: Thereupon Liang became Commandery Administrator of Kuaiji, and Ji became Assistant General, pacifying the subordinate counties.

In the seventh month of the first year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen She and others arose in Daze. That ninth month, the Commandery Administrator of Kuaiji, Tong, said to Liang: "West of the Yangtze all have rebelled; this is also the time when Heaven destroys Qin. I have heard that he who acts first controls others, while he who acts later is controlled by others. I wish to raise troops and have you and Huan Chu as generals." At that time Huan Chu was a fugitive hiding in the marshes. Liang said: "Huan Chu is a fugitive; no one knows where he is—only Ji knows." Liang then went out and instructed Ji to hold his sword outside and wait. Liang returned inside, sat with the Administrator, and said: "Please summon Ji and have him receive orders to summon Huan Chu." The Administrator said: "Very well." Liang summoned Ji inside. After a moment, Liang gave Ji a meaningful look and said: "It can be done now!" Thereupon Ji drew his sword and beheaded the Administrator. Xiang Liang took the Administrator's head and donned his seal and ribbons. The gate attendants were greatly alarmed and in disorder; those Ji struck down numbered several tens or hundreds. Everyone in the prefecture was terrified into submission; none dared rise. Liang then summoned the former heroic officials he knew, explained to them why he was undertaking this great affair, and thereupon raised troops in Wu. He sent people to take control of subordinate counties, obtaining eight thousand crack troops. Liang appointed the heroes of Wu as colonels, captains, and majors. There was one man who was not given appointment and spoke to Liang about it. Liang said: "Previously at a certain funeral I had you manage a certain matter, and you could not handle it; for this reason I cannot employ you." The crowd was then all convinced. Thereupon Liang became Commandery Administrator of Kuaiji, and Ji became Assistant General, pacifying the subordinate counties.

sentences.zh: 廣陵人召平於是為陳王徇廣陵，未能下。

translations.text: Zhao Ping of Guangling was at that time pacifying Guangling for King Chen but had not yet been able to take it.

sentences.zh: 聞陳王敗走，秦兵又且至，乃渡江矯陳王命，拜梁為楚王上柱國。

translations.text: Hearing that King Chen had been defeated and fled, and that Qin troops were about to arrive, he crossed the Yangtze, falsely invoked King Chen's command, and appointed Liang as Supreme Pillar of State of the King of Chu.

sentences.zh: 曰：「江東已定，急引兵西擊秦。」

translations.text: He said: "The east of the Yangtze is already settled; urgently lead troops west to attack Qin."

sentences.zh: 項梁乃以八千人渡江而西。

translations.text: Xiang Liang then crossed the Yangtze westward with eight thousand men.

sentences.zh: 聞陳嬰已下東陽，使使欲與連和俱西。

translations.text: Hearing that Chen Ying had already taken Dongyang, he sent an envoy wishing to join forces with him and go west together.

sentences.zh: 陳嬰者，故東陽令史，居縣中，素信謹，稱為長者。

translations.text: Chen Ying was a former clerk of the Dongyang magistrate; residing in the county, he had always been trustworthy and careful, known as an elder.

sentences.zh: 東陽少年殺其令，相聚數千人，欲置長，無適用，乃請陳嬰。

translations.text: The young men of Dongyang killed their magistrate and assembled several thousand men; wishing to establish a leader but finding none suitable, they invited Chen Ying.

sentences.zh: 嬰謝不能，遂彊立嬰為長，縣中從者得二萬人。

translations.text: Ying declined saying he was unable, but they forcibly made Ying their leader; those who followed him from the county numbered twenty thousand.

sentences.zh: 少年欲立嬰便為王，異軍蒼頭特起。

translations.text: The young men wished to make Ying king immediately, establishing an exceptional army distinguished by its black-headed [common] origins.

sentences.zh: 陳嬰母謂嬰曰：「自我為汝家婦，未嘗聞汝先古之有貴者。

translations.text: Chen Ying's mother said to Ying: "Since I became your family's daughter-in-law, I have never heard that your ancestors had anyone of high rank.

sentences.zh: 今暴得大名，不祥。

translations.text: Now to suddenly gain great fame is inauspicious.

sentences.zh: 不如有所屬，事成猶得封侯，事敗易以亡，非世所指名也。」

translations.text: It would be better to attach yourself to someone; if the affair succeeds you can still be enfeoffed as a marquis; if it fails you can easily escape, and you will not be one singled out by name."

sentences.zh: 嬰乃不敢為王。

translations.text: Ying then did not dare become king.

sentences.zh: 謂其軍吏曰：「項氏世世將家，有名於楚。

translations.text: He told his military officers: "The Xiang clan has been a family of generals for generations and is famous in Chu.

sentences.zh: 今欲舉大事，將非其人，不可。

translations.text: Now if we wish to undertake a great affair, the general must not be the wrong person.

sentences.zh: 我倚名族，亡秦必矣。」

translations.text: If I rely on a renowned clan, the destruction of Qin is certain."

sentences.zh: 於是眾從其言，以兵屬項梁。

translations.text: Thereupon the multitude followed his words and submitted their troops to Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 項梁渡淮，黥布、蒲將軍亦以兵屬焉。

translations.text: Xiang Liang crossed the Huai; Qing Bu and General Pu also brought their troops to join him.

sentences.zh: 凡六七萬人，軍下邳。

translations.text: In all sixty to seventy thousand men, they encamped at Xiapei.

Zhao Ping of Guangling was at that time pacifying Guangling for King Chen but had not yet been able to take it. Hearing that King Chen had been defeated and fled, and that Qin troops were about to arrive, he crossed the Yangtze, falsely invoked King Chen's command, and appointed Liang as Supreme Pillar of State of the King of Chu. He said: "The east of the Yangtze is already settled; urgently lead troops west to attack Qin." Xiang Liang then crossed the Yangtze westward with eight thousand men. Hearing that Chen Ying had already taken Dongyang, he sent an envoy wishing to join forces with him and go west together. Chen Ying was a former clerk of the Dongyang magistrate; residing in the county, he had always been trustworthy and careful, known as an elder. The young men of Dongyang killed their magistrate and assembled several thousand men; wishing to establish a leader but finding none suitable, they invited Chen Ying. Ying declined saying he was unable, but they forcibly made Ying their leader; those who followed him from the county numbered twenty thousand. The young men wished to make Ying king immediately, establishing an exceptional army distinguished by its black-headed [common] origins. Chen Ying's mother said to Ying: "Since I became your family's daughter-in-law, I have never heard that your ancestors had anyone of high rank. Now to suddenly gain great fame is inauspicious. It would be better to attach yourself to someone; if the affair succeeds you can still be enfeoffed as a marquis; if it fails you can easily escape, and you will not be one singled out by name." Ying then did not dare become king. He told his military officers: "The Xiang clan has been a family of generals for generations and is famous in Chu. Now if we wish to undertake a great affair, the general must not be the wrong person. If I rely on a renowned clan, the destruction of Qin is certain." Thereupon the multitude followed his words and submitted their troops to Xiang Liang. Xiang Liang crossed the Huai; Qing Bu and General Pu also brought their troops to join him. In all sixty to seventy thousand men, they encamped at Xiapei.

sentences.zh: 當是時，秦嘉已立景駒為楚王，軍彭城東，欲距項梁。

translations.text: At that time, Qin Jia had already installed Jing Ju as King of Chu and was encamped east of Pengcheng, intending to resist Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 項梁謂軍吏曰：「陳王先首事，戰不利，未聞所在。

translations.text: Xiang Liang said to his military officers: "King Chen was the first to initiate the affair; battles went unfavorably, and we have not heard where he is.

sentences.zh: 今秦嘉倍陳王而立景駒，逆無道。」

translations.text: Now Qin Jia has betrayed King Chen and installed Jing Ju—this is rebellion against the Way."

sentences.zh: 乃進兵擊秦嘉。

translations.text: He then advanced his troops and attacked Qin Jia.

sentences.zh: 秦嘉軍敗走，追之至胡陵。

translations.text: Qin Jia's army was defeated and fled; pursuing them to Huling.

sentences.zh: 嘉還戰一日，嘉死，軍降。

translations.text: Jia turned and fought for one day; Jia died and his army surrendered.

sentences.zh: 景駒走死梁地。

translations.text: Jing Ju fled and died in the Liang region.

sentences.zh: 項梁已并秦嘉軍，軍胡陵，將引軍而西。

translations.text: Having absorbed Qin Jia's army, Xiang Liang encamped at Huling, preparing to lead his army westward.

sentences.zh: 章邯軍至栗，項梁使別將朱雞石、餘樊君與戰。

translations.text: Zhang Han's army arrived at Li; Xiang Liang sent separate commanders Zhu Jishi and Lord Yufan to do battle.

sentences.zh: 餘樊君死。

translations.text: Lord Yufan died.

sentences.zh: 朱雞石軍敗，亡走胡陵。

translations.text: Zhu Jishi's army was defeated and fled back to Huling.

sentences.zh: 項梁乃引兵入薛，誅雞石。

translations.text: Xiang Liang then led his troops into Xue and executed Jishi.

sentences.zh: 項梁前使項羽別攻襄城，襄城堅守不下。

translations.text: Xiang Liang previously had sent Xiang Yu separately to attack Xiangcheng; Xiangcheng held firm and did not fall.

sentences.zh: 已拔，皆阬之。

translations.text: Once it was taken, all were buried alive.

sentences.zh: 還報項梁。

translations.text: He returned and reported to Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 項梁聞陳王定死，召諸別將會薛計事。

translations.text: Xiang Liang heard that King Chen had definitely died, so he summoned the separate commanders to meet at Xue to plan matters.

sentences.zh: 此時沛公亦起沛，往焉。

translations.text: At this time Pei Gong had also arisen at Pei and went there.

At that time, Qin Jia had already installed Jing Ju as King of Chu and was encamped east of Pengcheng, intending to resist Xiang Liang. Xiang Liang said to his military officers: "King Chen was the first to initiate the affair; battles went unfavorably, and we have not heard where he is. Now Qin Jia has betrayed King Chen and installed Jing Ju—this is rebellion against the Way." He then advanced his troops and attacked Qin Jia. Qin Jia's army was defeated and fled; pursuing them to Huling. Jia turned and fought for one day; Jia died and his army surrendered. Jing Ju fled and died in the Liang region. Having absorbed Qin Jia's army, Xiang Liang encamped at Huling, preparing to lead his army westward. Zhang Han's army arrived at Li; Xiang Liang sent separate commanders Zhu Jishi and Lord Yufan to do battle. Lord Yufan died. Zhu Jishi's army was defeated and fled back to Huling. Xiang Liang then led his troops into Xue and executed Jishi. Xiang Liang previously had sent Xiang Yu separately to attack Xiangcheng; Xiangcheng held firm and did not fall. Once it was taken, all were buried alive. He returned and reported to Xiang Liang. Xiang Liang heard that King Chen had definitely died, so he summoned the separate commanders to meet at Xue to plan matters. At this time Pei Gong had also arisen at Pei and went there.

sentences.zh: 居鄛人范增，年七十，素居家，好奇計，往說項梁曰：「陳勝敗碧當。

translations.text: Fan Zeng, a man from Ju, seventy years old, had always stayed at home and liked extraordinary schemes; he went and persuaded Xiang Liang, saying: "Chen She's failure was deserved.

sentences.zh: 夫秦滅六國，楚最無罪。

translations.text: When Qin destroyed the Six States, Chu was the most blameless.

sentences.zh: 自懷王入秦不反，楚人憐之至今，故楚南公曰『楚雖三戶，亡秦必楚』也。

translations.text: Since King Huai entered Qin and did not return, the Chu people have pitied him to this day; therefore the Nan Gong of Chu said 'Though Chu may have but three clans remaining, he who destroys Qin will surely be Chu.'

sentences.zh: 今陳勝首事，不立楚後而自立，其勢不長。

translations.text: Now Chen She initiated the affair but did not establish a descendant of Chu and instead made himself king; his power could not last.

sentences.zh: 今君起江東，楚蜂午之將皆爭附君者，以君世世楚將，為能復立楚之後也。」

translations.text: Now you have arisen in the east of the Yangtze, and all the Chu generals swarming like bees compete to attach themselves to you because you are from a family of Chu generals for generations and are capable of restoring a descendant of Chu."

sentences.zh: 於是項梁然其言，乃求楚懷王孫心民閒，為人牧羊，立以為楚懷王，從民所望也。

translations.text: Thereupon Xiang Liang agreed with his words and sought out Xin, grandson of King Huai of Chu, among the common people—he was herding sheep—and installed him as King Huai, following what the people hoped for.

sentences.zh: 陳嬰為楚上柱國，封五縣，與懷王都盱臺。

translations.text: Chen Ying was made Supreme Pillar of State of Chu, enfeoffed with five counties, and resided with King Huai at Xutai.

sentences.zh: 項梁自號為武信君。

translations.text: Xiang Liang styled himself Lord of Martial Trust.

Fan Zeng, a man from Ju, seventy years old, had always stayed at home and liked extraordinary schemes; he went and persuaded Xiang Liang, saying: "Chen She's failure was deserved. When Qin destroyed the Six States, Chu was the most blameless. Since King Huai entered Qin and did not return, the Chu people have pitied him to this day; therefore the Nan Gong of Chu said 'Though Chu may have but three clans remaining, he who destroys Qin will surely be Chu.' Now Chen She initiated the affair but did not establish a descendant of Chu and instead made himself king; his power could not last. Now you have arisen in the east of the Yangtze, and all the Chu generals swarming like bees compete to attach themselves to you because you are from a family of Chu generals for generations and are capable of restoring a descendant of Chu." Thereupon Xiang Liang agreed with his words and sought out Xin, grandson of King Huai of Chu, among the common people—he was herding sheep—and installed him as King Huai, following what the people hoped for. Chen Ying was made Supreme Pillar of State of Chu, enfeoffed with five counties, and resided with King Huai at Xutai. Xiang Liang styled himself Lord of Martial Trust.

sentences.zh: 居數月，引兵攻亢父，與齊田榮、司馬龍且軍救東阿，大破秦軍於東阿。

translations.text: After several months, he led troops to attack Kangfu, joining with Qi's Tian Rong and Major Long Ju's armies to rescue Dong'e, greatly defeating the Qin army at Dong'e.

sentences.zh: 田榮即引兵歸，逐其王假。

translations.text: Tian Rong then led his troops back and expelled his king, Jia.

sentences.zh: 假亡走楚。

translations.text: Jia fled to Chu.

sentences.zh: 假相田角亡走趙。

translations.text: Jia's Prime Minister Tian Jiao fled to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 角弟田閒故齊將，居趙不敢歸。

translations.text: Jiao's younger brother Tian Jian, formerly a Qi general, was residing in Zhao and did not dare return.

sentences.zh: 田榮立田儋子市為齊王。

translations.text: Tian Rong installed Tian Dan's son Shi as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 項梁已破東阿下軍，遂追秦軍。

translations.text: Having broken the army below Dong'e, Xiang Liang pursued the Qin army.

sentences.zh: 數使使趣齊兵，欲與俱西。

translations.text: He repeatedly sent envoys to urge Qi troops, wishing to go west together.

sentences.zh: 田榮曰：「楚殺田假，趙殺田角、田閒，乃發兵。」

translations.text: Tian Rong said: "If Chu kills Tian Jia and Zhao kills Tian Jiao and Tian Jian, then I will send troops."

sentences.zh: 項梁曰：「田假為與國之王，窮來從我，不忍殺之。」

translations.text: Xiang Liang said: "Tian Jia was the king of an allied state; he came to me in distress—I cannot bear to kill him."

sentences.zh: 趙亦不殺田角、田閒以市於齊。

translations.text: Zhao also would not kill Tian Jiao and Tian Jian to trade with Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊遂不肯發兵助楚。

translations.text: Qi thereupon refused to send troops to aid Chu.

sentences.zh: 項梁使沛公及項羽別攻城陽，屠之。

translations.text: Xiang Liang sent Pei Gong and Xiang Yu separately to attack Chengyang and massacre it.

sentences.zh: 西破秦軍濮陽東，秦兵收入濮陽。

translations.text: They defeated the Qin army west at Puyang, then east; the Qin troops withdrew into Puyang.

sentences.zh: 沛公、項羽乃攻定陶。

translations.text: Pei Gong and Xiang Yu then attacked Dingtao.

sentences.zh: 定陶未下，去，西略地至雝丘，大破秦軍，斬李由。

translations.text: Dingtao did not fall, so they departed and went west to take territory, reaching Yongqiu, where they greatly defeated the Qin army and beheaded Li You.

sentences.zh: 還攻外黃，外黃未下。

translations.text: Returning, they attacked Waihuang, but Waihuang did not fall.

After several months, he led troops to attack Kangfu, joining with Qi's Tian Rong and Major Long Ju's armies to rescue Dong'e, greatly defeating the Qin army at Dong'e. Tian Rong then led his troops back and expelled his king, Jia. Jia fled to Chu. Jia's Prime Minister Tian Jiao fled to Zhao. Jiao's younger brother Tian Jian, formerly a Qi general, was residing in Zhao and did not dare return. Tian Rong installed Tian Dan's son Shi as King of Qi. Having broken the army below Dong'e, Xiang Liang pursued the Qin army. He repeatedly sent envoys to urge Qi troops, wishing to go west together. Tian Rong said: "If Chu kills Tian Jia and Zhao kills Tian Jiao and Tian Jian, then I will send troops." Xiang Liang said: "Tian Jia was the king of an allied state; he came to me in distress—I cannot bear to kill him." Zhao also would not kill Tian Jiao and Tian Jian to trade with Qi. Qi thereupon refused to send troops to aid Chu. Xiang Liang sent Pei Gong and Xiang Yu separately to attack Chengyang and massacre it. They defeated the Qin army west at Puyang, then east; the Qin troops withdrew into Puyang. Pei Gong and Xiang Yu then attacked Dingtao. Dingtao did not fall, so they departed and went west to take territory, reaching Yongqiu, where they greatly defeated the Qin army and beheaded Li You. Returning, they attacked Waihuang, but Waihuang did not fall.

sentences.zh: 項梁起東阿，西，（北）［比］至定陶，再破秦軍，項羽等又斬李由，益輕秦，有驕色。

translations.text: Xiang Liang arose from Dong'e and went west, arriving at Dingtao by comparison, defeating the Qin army twice; Xiang Yu and others also beheaded Li You, and increasingly despised Qin, showing an arrogant bearing.

sentences.zh: 宋義乃諫項梁曰：「戰勝而將驕卒惰者敗。

translations.text: Song Yi then remonstrated with Xiang Liang, saying: "When battles are won but the general grows arrogant and the troops lazy, defeat follows.

sentences.zh: 今卒少惰矣，秦兵日益，臣為君畏之。」

translations.text: Now the troops are becoming slightly lazy, while Qin troops increase daily; I fear this for you."

sentences.zh: 項梁弗聽。

translations.text: Xiang Liang did not listen.

sentences.zh: 乃使宋義使於齊。

translations.text: He then sent Song Yi as envoy to Qi.

sentences.zh: 道遇齊使者高陵君顯，曰：「公將見武信君乎？」

translations.text: On the road he met the Qi envoy, Lord Gaolin Xian, who said: "Are you going to see Lord Wuxin?"
He said: "Yes."

sentences.zh: 曰：「臣論武信君軍必敗。

translations.text: He said: "I predict that Lord Wuxin's army will certainly be defeated.

sentences.zh: 公徐行即免死，疾行則及禍。」

translations.text: If you walk slowly you will avoid death; if you walk quickly you will meet disaster."

sentences.zh: 秦果悉起兵益章邯，擊楚軍，大破之定陶，項梁死。

translations.text: Qin indeed mustered all its troops to reinforce Zhang Han, attacked the Chu army, and greatly defeated it at Dingtao; Xiang Liang died.

sentences.zh: 沛公、項羽去外黃攻陳留，陳留堅守不能下。

translations.text: Pei Gong and Xiang Yu left Waihuang to attack Chenliu, but Chenliu held firm and could not be taken.

sentences.zh: 沛公、項羽相與謀曰：「今項梁軍破，士卒恐。」

translations.text: Pei Gong and Xiang Yu consulted with each other, saying: "Now that Xiang Liang's army is broken, the officers and troops are fearful."

sentences.zh: 乃與呂臣軍俱引兵而東。

translations.text: They then led their troops eastward together with Lü Chen's army.

sentences.zh: 呂臣軍彭城東，項羽軍彭城西，沛公軍碭。

translations.text: Lü Chen's army was east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and Pei Gong's army at Dang.

Xiang Liang arose from Dong'e and went west, arriving at Dingtao by comparison, defeating the Qin army twice; Xiang Yu and others also beheaded Li You, and increasingly despised Qin, showing an arrogant bearing. Song Yi then remonstrated with Xiang Liang, saying: "When battles are won but the general grows arrogant and the troops lazy, defeat follows. Now the troops are becoming slightly lazy, while Qin troops increase daily; I fear this for you." Xiang Liang did not listen. He then sent Song Yi as envoy to Qi. On the road he met the Qi envoy, Lord Gaolin Xian, who said: "Are you going to see Lord Wuxin?" He said: "Yes." He said: "I predict that Lord Wuxin's army will certainly be defeated. If you walk slowly you will avoid death; if you walk quickly you will meet disaster." Qin indeed mustered all its troops to reinforce Zhang Han, attacked the Chu army, and greatly defeated it at Dingtao; Xiang Liang died. Pei Gong and Xiang Yu left Waihuang to attack Chenliu, but Chenliu held firm and could not be taken. Pei Gong and Xiang Yu consulted with each other, saying: "Now that Xiang Liang's army is broken, the officers and troops are fearful." They then led their troops eastward together with Lü Chen's army. Lü Chen's army was east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and Pei Gong's army at Dang.

sentences.zh: 章邯已破項梁軍，則以為楚地兵不足憂，乃渡河擊趙，大破之。

translations.text: Having broken Xiang Liang's army, Zhang Han considered that Chu territory's troops were not worth worrying about, so he crossed the Yellow River to attack Zhao and greatly defeated them.

sentences.zh: 當此時，趙歇為王，陳餘為將，張耳為相，皆走入鉅鹿城。

translations.text: At this time, Zhao Xie was king, Chen Yu was general, and Zhang Er was prime minister; all fled into Julu city.

sentences.zh: 章邯令王離、涉閒圍鉅鹿，章邯軍其南，筑甬道而輸之粟。

translations.text: Zhang Han ordered Wang Li and She Jian to surround Julu, while Zhang Han's army was to the south, constructing a walled supply road to transport grain.

sentences.zh: 陳餘為將，將卒數萬人而軍鉅鹿之北，此所謂河北之軍也。

translations.text: Chen Yu as general led several tens of thousands of troops and encamped north of Julu; this was called the army north of the Yellow River.

Having broken Xiang Liang's army, Zhang Han considered that Chu territory's troops were not worth worrying about, so he crossed the Yellow River to attack Zhao and greatly defeated them. At this time, Zhao Xie was king, Chen Yu was general, and Zhang Er was prime minister; all fled into Julu city. Zhang Han ordered Wang Li and She Jian to surround Julu, while Zhang Han's army was to the south, constructing a walled supply road to transport grain. Chen Yu as general led several tens of thousands of troops and encamped north of Julu; this was called the army north of the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 楚兵已破於定陶，懷王恐，從盱臺之彭城，并項羽、呂臣軍自將之。

translations.text: The Chu army having been broken at Dingtao, King Huai was afraid and moved from Xutai to Pengcheng, combining Xiang Yu's and Lü Chen's armies to command them himself.

sentences.zh: 以呂臣為司徒，以其父呂青為令尹。

translations.text: He made Lü Chen Minister of Ceremonies and his father Lü Qing Grand Councillor.

sentences.zh: 以沛公為碭郡長，封為武安侯，將碭郡兵。

translations.text: He made Pei Gong Administrator of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu'an, and had him command the troops of Dang Commandery.

The Chu army having been broken at Dingtao, King Huai was afraid and moved from Xutai to Pengcheng, combining Xiang Yu's and Lü Chen's armies to command them himself. He made Lü Chen Minister of Ceremonies and his father Lü Qing Grand Councillor. He made Pei Gong Administrator of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu'an, and had him command the troops of Dang Commandery.

sentences.zh: 初，宋義所遇齊使者高陵君顯在楚軍，見楚王曰：「宋義論武信君之軍必敗，居數日，軍果敗。

translations.text: Earlier, the Qi envoy Lord Gaolin Xian whom Song Yi had met was with the Chu army and saw the King of Chu, saying: "Song Yi predicted that Lord Wuxin's army would certainly be defeated, and after several days, the army was indeed defeated.

sentences.zh: 兵未戰而先見敗徵，此可謂知兵矣。」

translations.text: That he could foresee signs of defeat before troops engaged in battle—this can be called understanding warfare."

sentences.zh: 王召宋義與計事而大說之，因置以為上將軍，項羽為魯公，為次將，范增為末將，救趙。

translations.text: The king summoned Song Yi to consult on affairs and was greatly pleased with him; consequently he appointed him Supreme General, made Xiang Yu Duke of Lu as second general, and Fan Zeng final general, to rescue Zhao.

sentences.zh: 諸別將皆屬宋義，號為卿子冠軍。

translations.text: All the separate generals were subordinate to Song Yi, who was titled Lord Superior to Ministers.

sentences.zh: 行至安陽，留四十六日不進。

translations.text: They marched to Anyang and remained there for forty-six days without advancing.

sentences.zh: 項羽曰：「吾聞秦軍圍趙王鉅鹿，疾引兵渡河，楚擊其外，趙應其內，破秦軍必矣。」

translations.text: Xiang Yu said: "I have heard that the Qin army has surrounded King Zhao at Julu; we should quickly lead troops across the river—Chu attacks from outside, Zhao responds from inside, and the Qin army will certainly be broken."

sentences.zh: 宋義曰：「不然。

translations.text: Song Yi said: "Not so.

sentences.zh: 夫搏牛之虻不可以破蟣虱。

translations.text: A gadfly that strikes an ox cannot break lice and nits.

sentences.zh: 今秦攻趙，戰勝則兵罷，我承其敝；

translations.text: Now Qin attacks Zhao; if they win the battle their troops will be exhausted, and we take advantage of their exhaustion;

sentences.zh: 不勝，則我引兵鼓行而西，必舉秦矣。

translations.text: if they do not win, then we lead troops beating drums westward and will certainly take Qin.

sentences.zh: 故不如先鬬秦趙。

translations.text: Therefore it is better to let Qin and Zhao fight first.

sentences.zh: 夫被堅執銳，義不如公；

translations.text: As for wearing armor and wielding sharp weapons, I am not your equal;

sentences.zh: 坐而運策，公不如義。」

translations.text: as for sitting and devising strategies, you are not my equal."

sentences.zh: 因下令軍中曰：「猛如虎，很如羊，貪如狼，彊不可使者，皆斬之。」

translations.text: He then issued an order throughout the army: "Those who are fierce as tigers, stubborn as sheep, greedy as wolves, and too headstrong to be commanded shall all be beheaded."

sentences.zh: 乃遣其子宋襄相齊，身送之至無鹽，飲酒高會。

translations.text: He then sent his son Song Xiang as prime minister to Qi, personally escorting him to Wuyan, where they drank wine in grand celebration.

sentences.zh: 天寒大雨，士卒凍饑。

translations.text: The weather was cold with heavy rain; the officers and troops were freezing and starving.

sentences.zh: 項羽曰：「將戮力而攻秦，久留不行。

translations.text: Xiang Yu said: "We are to unite our strength to attack Qin, yet we remain long without moving.

sentences.zh: 今歲饑民貧，士卒食芋菽，軍無見糧，乃飲酒高會，不引兵渡河因趙食，與趙并力攻秦，乃曰『承其敝』。

translations.text: This year there is famine and the people are poor; the officers and troops eat taro and beans, the army has no stored grain, yet he drinks wine in grand celebration and does not lead troops across the river to obtain food from Zhao and join forces with Zhao to attack Qin, but instead says 'take advantage of their exhaustion.'

sentences.zh: 夫以秦之彊，攻新造之趙，其勢必舉趙。

translations.text: Given Qin's strength attacking newly established Zhao, the situation will certainly result in Zhao being taken.

sentences.zh: 趙舉而秦彊，何敝之承！

translations.text: When Zhao is taken and Qin grows stronger, what exhaustion is there to take advantage of!

sentences.zh: 且國兵新破，王坐不安席，埽境內而專屬於將軍，國家安危，在此一舉。

translations.text: Moreover, our state's army is newly broken, the king sits uneasy in his seat, having swept the territory to entrust everything to the general; the state's safety or danger rests on this single action.

sentences.zh: 今不恤士卒而徇其私，非社稷之臣。」

translations.text: Now he does not care for the officers and troops but pursues his private interests—he is not a minister of the altars of soil and grain."

sentences.zh: 項羽晨朝上將軍宋義，即其帳中斬宋義頭，出令軍中曰：「宋義與齊謀反楚，楚王陰令羽誅之。」

translations.text: Xiang Yu at morning audience with Supreme General Song Yi entered his tent and beheaded Song Yi's head, then issued orders throughout the army saying: "Song Yi conspired with Qi to rebel against Chu; the King of Chu secretly ordered Yu to execute him."

sentences.zh: 當是時，諸將皆慴服，莫敢枝梧。

translations.text: At that time, all the generals were terrified into submission; none dared resist.

sentences.zh: 皆曰：「首立楚者，將軍家也。

translations.text: They all said: "It was the general's family who first established Chu.

sentences.zh: 今將軍誅亂。」

translations.text: Now the general has executed disorder."

sentences.zh: 乃相與共立羽為假上將軍。

translations.text: Thereupon they together installed Yu as Acting Supreme General.

sentences.zh: 使人追宋義子，及之齊，殺之。

translations.text: He sent men to pursue Song Yi's son, caught up with him in Qi, and killed him.

sentences.zh: 使桓楚報命於懷王。

translations.text: He sent Huan Chu to report the order to King Huai.

sentences.zh: 懷王因使項羽為上將軍，當陽君、蒲將軍皆屬項羽。

translations.text: King Huai consequently made Xiang Yu Supreme General; Lord Dangyang and General Pu were both subordinated to Xiang Yu.

Earlier, the Qi envoy Lord Gaolin Xian whom Song Yi had met was with the Chu army and saw the King of Chu, saying: "Song Yi predicted that Lord Wuxin's army would certainly be defeated, and after several days, the army was indeed defeated. That he could foresee signs of defeat before troops engaged in battle—this can be called understanding warfare." The king summoned Song Yi to consult on affairs and was greatly pleased with him; consequently he appointed him Supreme General, made Xiang Yu Duke of Lu as second general, and Fan Zeng final general, to rescue Zhao. All the separate generals were subordinate to Song Yi, who was titled Lord Superior to Ministers. They marched to Anyang and remained there for forty-six days without advancing. Xiang Yu said: "I have heard that the Qin army has surrounded King Zhao at Julu; we should quickly lead troops across the river—Chu attacks from outside, Zhao responds from inside, and the Qin army will certainly be broken." Song Yi said: "Not so. A gadfly that strikes an ox cannot break lice and nits. Now Qin attacks Zhao; if they win the battle their troops will be exhausted, and we take advantage of their exhaustion; if they do not win, then we lead troops beating drums westward and will certainly take Qin. Therefore it is better to let Qin and Zhao fight first. As for wearing armor and wielding sharp weapons, I am not your equal; as for sitting and devising strategies, you are not my equal." He then issued an order throughout the army: "Those who are fierce as tigers, stubborn as sheep, greedy as wolves, and too headstrong to be commanded shall all be beheaded." He then sent his son Song Xiang as prime minister to Qi, personally escorting him to Wuyan, where they drank wine in grand celebration. The weather was cold with heavy rain; the officers and troops were freezing and starving. Xiang Yu said: "We are to unite our strength to attack Qin, yet we remain long without moving. This year there is famine and the people are poor; the officers and troops eat taro and beans, the army has no stored grain, yet he drinks wine in grand celebration and does not lead troops across the river to obtain food from Zhao and join forces with Zhao to attack Qin, but instead says 'take advantage of their exhaustion.' Given Qin's strength attacking newly established Zhao, the situation will certainly result in Zhao being taken. When Zhao is taken and Qin grows stronger, what exhaustion is there to take advantage of! Moreover, our state's army is newly broken, the king sits uneasy in his seat, having swept the territory to entrust everything to the general; the state's safety or danger rests on this single action. Now he does not care for the officers and troops but pursues his private interests—he is not a minister of the altars of soil and grain." Xiang Yu at morning audience with Supreme General Song Yi entered his tent and beheaded Song Yi's head, then issued orders throughout the army saying: "Song Yi conspired with Qi to rebel against Chu; the King of Chu secretly ordered Yu to execute him." At that time, all the generals were terrified into submission; none dared resist. They all said: "It was the general's family who first established Chu. Now the general has executed disorder." Thereupon they together installed Yu as Acting Supreme General. He sent men to pursue Song Yi's son, caught up with him in Qi, and killed him. He sent Huan Chu to report the order to King Huai. King Huai consequently made Xiang Yu Supreme General; Lord Dangyang and General Pu were both subordinated to Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 項羽已殺卿子冠軍，威震楚國，名聞諸侯。

translations.text: Having killed Lord Superior to Ministers, Xiang Yu's authority shook the state of Chu and his fame was heard among the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 乃遣當陽君、蒲將軍將卒二萬渡河，救鉅鹿。

translations.text: He then dispatched Lord Dangyang and General Pu to lead twenty thousand troops across the river to rescue Julu.

sentences.zh: 戰少利，陳餘復請兵。

translations.text: The battle went slightly in their favor; Chen Yu again requested troops.

sentences.zh: 項羽乃悉引兵渡河，皆沈船，破釜甑，燒廬舍，持三日糧，以示士卒必死，無一還心。

translations.text: Xiang Yu then led all his troops across the river, sank all the boats, smashed the cooking pots and cauldrons, burned the shelters, and carried only three days' rations, to show his officers and troops they must fight to the death with no thought of return.

sentences.zh: 於是至則圍王離，與秦軍遇，九戰，絕其甬道，大破之，殺蘇角，虜王離。

translations.text: Thereupon when they arrived they surrounded Wang Li, engaged the Qin army, fought nine battles, severed their supply corridor, greatly defeated them, killed Su Jiao, and captured Wang Li.

sentences.zh: 涉閒不降楚，自燒殺。

translations.text: She Jian would not surrender to Chu and burned himself to death.

sentences.zh: 當是時，楚兵冠諸侯。

translations.text: At that time, the Chu troops were foremost among the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 諸侯軍救鉅鹿下者十餘壁，莫敢縱兵。

translations.text: The feudal lords' armies rescuing those below Julu numbered over ten encampments, but none dared release their troops.

sentences.zh: 及楚擊秦，諸將皆從壁上觀。

translations.text: When Chu attacked Qin, all the generals watched from atop their ramparts.

sentences.zh: 楚戰士無不一以當十，楚兵呼聲動天，諸侯軍無不人人惴恐。

translations.text: Every Chu fighting man fought one against ten; the Chu troops' battle cries shook the heavens, and there was not a man in the feudal lords' armies who was not trembling in fear.

sentences.zh: 於是已破秦軍，項羽召見諸侯將，入轅門，無不膝行而前，莫敢仰視。

translations.text: Having thus broken the Qin army, Xiang Yu summoned to audience the feudal lords' generals; entering the gate with barriers, every one advanced on their knees, none daring to look up.

sentences.zh: 項羽由是始為諸侯上將軍，諸侯皆屬焉。

translations.text: From this time Xiang Yu first became Supreme General over the feudal lords, and all the feudal lords were subordinate to him.

Having killed Lord Superior to Ministers, Xiang Yu's authority shook the state of Chu and his fame was heard among the feudal lords. He then dispatched Lord Dangyang and General Pu to lead twenty thousand troops across the river to rescue Julu. The battle went slightly in their favor; Chen Yu again requested troops. Xiang Yu then led all his troops across the river, sank all the boats, smashed the cooking pots and cauldrons, burned the shelters, and carried only three days' rations, to show his officers and troops they must fight to the death with no thought of return. Thereupon when they arrived they surrounded Wang Li, engaged the Qin army, fought nine battles, severed their supply corridor, greatly defeated them, killed Su Jiao, and captured Wang Li. She Jian would not surrender to Chu and burned himself to death. At that time, the Chu troops were foremost among the feudal lords. The feudal lords' armies rescuing those below Julu numbered over ten encampments, but none dared release their troops. When Chu attacked Qin, all the generals watched from atop their ramparts. Every Chu fighting man fought one against ten; the Chu troops' battle cries shook the heavens, and there was not a man in the feudal lords' armies who was not trembling in fear. Having thus broken the Qin army, Xiang Yu summoned to audience the feudal lords' generals; entering the gate with barriers, every one advanced on their knees, none daring to look up. From this time Xiang Yu first became Supreme General over the feudal lords, and all the feudal lords were subordinate to him.

sentences.zh: 章邯軍棘原，項羽軍漳南，相持未戰。

translations.text: Zhang Han's army was at Jiyuan, Xiang Yu's army south of the Zhang River, confronting each other without battle.

sentences.zh: 秦軍數卻，二世使人讓章邯。

translations.text: The Qin army retreated several times; the Second Emperor sent men to reproach Zhang Han.

sentences.zh: 章邯恐，使長史欣請事。

translations.text: Zhang Han was afraid and sent Chief Clerk Xin to request instructions.

sentences.zh: 至咸陽，留司馬門三日，趙高不見，有不信之心。

translations.text: Reaching Xianyang, he remained at the Sima Gate for three days; Zhao Gao would not see him, and doubts arose in his heart.

sentences.zh: 長史欣恐，還走其軍，不敢出故道，趙高果使人追之，不及。

translations.text: Chief Clerk Xin was afraid and fled back to his army, not daring to take the usual route; Zhao Gao indeed sent men to pursue him but did not catch up.

sentences.zh: 欣至軍，報曰：「趙高用事於中，下無可為者。

translations.text: Xin reached the army and reported: "Zhao Gao handles affairs at court; below there is nothing that can be done.

sentences.zh: 今戰能勝，高必疾妒吾功；

translations.text: Now if we win battles, Gao will certainly be jealous and resent our achievements;

sentences.zh: 戰不能勝，不免於死。

translations.text: if we cannot win battles, we will not escape death.

sentences.zh: 願將軍孰計之。」

translations.text: I hope the general will carefully consider this."

sentences.zh: 陳餘亦遺章邯書曰：「白起為秦將，南征鄢郢，北阬馬服，攻城略地，不可勝計，而竟賜死。

translations.text: Chen Yu also sent a letter to Zhang Han saying: "Bai Qi as Qin general conquered Yan and Ying to the south, buried alive the forces of Ma Fu to the north, attacked cities and took territory beyond count, yet in the end was granted death.

sentences.zh: 蒙恬為秦將，北逐戎人，開榆中地數千里，竟斬陽周。

translations.text: Meng Tian as Qin general drove back the Rong people to the north, opened up territory at Yuzhong for several thousand li, yet was finally beheaded at Yangzhou.

sentences.zh: 何者？

translations.text: Why?

sentences.zh: 功多，秦不能盡封，因以法誅之。

translations.text: Their achievements were many; Qin could not enfeoff them all, so used the law to execute them.

sentences.zh: 今將軍為秦將三歲矣，所亡失以十萬數，而諸侯并起滋益多。

translations.text: Now the general has been Qin's general for three years; those lost and defeated number in the hundreds of thousands, yet the feudal lords rise together and increase ever more.

sentences.zh: 彼趙高素諛日久，今事急，亦恐二世誅之，故欲以法誅將軍以塞責，使人更代將軍以脫其禍。

translations.text: That Zhao Gao has long been accustomed to flattery; now that affairs are urgent, he also fears the Second Emperor will execute him, so wants to use the law to execute the general to evade responsibility, having someone else replace the general to escape his own disaster.

sentences.zh: 夫將軍居外久，多內卻，有功亦誅，無功亦誅。

translations.text: The general has been abroad long with many internal setbacks; whether you have achievements or not, you will be executed.

sentences.zh: 且天之亡秦，無愚智皆知之。

translations.text: Moreover, that Heaven will destroy Qin is known by all, foolish or wise.

sentences.zh: 今將軍內不能直諫，外為亡國將，孤特獨立而欲常存，豈不哀哉！

translations.text: Now the general internally cannot remonstrate directly, and externally is a general of a perishing state, standing isolated and alone yet wishing to survive constantly—how pitiful!

sentences.zh: 將軍何不還兵與諸侯為從，約共攻秦，分王其地，南面稱孤；

translations.text: Why does the general not turn his troops and form a vertical alliance with the feudal lords, agree to attack Qin together, divide and rule its territory, face south and call yourself lord?

sentences.zh: 此孰與身伏鈇質，妻子為僇乎？」

translations.text: Which is better—this, or having your body subjected to the axe and chopping block, your wife and children executed?"

sentences.zh: 章邯狐疑，陰使候始成使項羽，欲約。

translations.text: Zhang Han was doubtful and secretly sent Hou Shicheng as envoy to Xiang Yu, seeking an agreement.

sentences.zh: 約未成，項羽使蒲將軍日夜引兵度三戶，軍漳南，與秦戰，再破之。

translations.text: Before the agreement was concluded, Xiang Yu had General Pu lead troops day and night across Sanhu, encamped south of the Zhang River, and fought with Qin, defeating them twice.

sentences.zh: 項羽悉引兵擊秦軍汙水上，大破之。

translations.text: Xiang Yu led all his troops to attack the Qin army at Wu River, greatly defeating them.

Zhang Han's army was at Jiyuan, Xiang Yu's army south of the Zhang River, confronting each other without battle. The Qin army retreated several times; the Second Emperor sent men to reproach Zhang Han. Zhang Han was afraid and sent Chief Clerk Xin to request instructions. Reaching Xianyang, he remained at the Sima Gate for three days; Zhao Gao would not see him, and doubts arose in his heart. Chief Clerk Xin was afraid and fled back to his army, not daring to take the usual route; Zhao Gao indeed sent men to pursue him but did not catch up. Xin reached the army and reported: "Zhao Gao handles affairs at court; below there is nothing that can be done. Now if we win battles, Gao will certainly be jealous and resent our achievements; if we cannot win battles, we will not escape death. I hope the general will carefully consider this." Chen Yu also sent a letter to Zhang Han saying: "Bai Qi as Qin general conquered Yan and Ying to the south, buried alive the forces of Ma Fu to the north, attacked cities and took territory beyond count, yet in the end was granted death. Meng Tian as Qin general drove back the Rong people to the north, opened up territory at Yuzhong for several thousand li, yet was finally beheaded at Yangzhou. Why? Their achievements were many; Qin could not enfeoff them all, so used the law to execute them. Now the general has been Qin's general for three years; those lost and defeated number in the hundreds of thousands, yet the feudal lords rise together and increase ever more. That Zhao Gao has long been accustomed to flattery; now that affairs are urgent, he also fears the Second Emperor will execute him, so wants to use the law to execute the general to evade responsibility, having someone else replace the general to escape his own disaster. The general has been abroad long with many internal setbacks; whether you have achievements or not, you will be executed. Moreover, that Heaven will destroy Qin is known by all, foolish or wise. Now the general internally cannot remonstrate directly, and externally is a general of a perishing state, standing isolated and alone yet wishing to survive constantly—how pitiful! Why does the general not turn his troops and form a vertical alliance with the feudal lords, agree to attack Qin together, divide and rule its territory, face south and call yourself lord? Which is better—this, or having your body subjected to the axe and chopping block, your wife and children executed?" Zhang Han was doubtful and secretly sent Hou Shicheng as envoy to Xiang Yu, seeking an agreement. Before the agreement was concluded, Xiang Yu had General Pu lead troops day and night across Sanhu, encamped south of the Zhang River, and fought with Qin, defeating them twice. Xiang Yu led all his troops to attack the Qin army at Wu River, greatly defeating them.

sentences.zh: 章邯使人見項羽，欲約。

translations.text: Zhang Han sent men to see Xiang Yu, seeking an agreement.

sentences.zh: 項羽召軍吏謀曰：「糧少，欲聽其約。」

translations.text: Xiang Yu summoned his military officers to deliberate, saying: "Grain is scarce; I wish to accept their agreement."

sentences.zh: 軍吏皆曰：「善。」

translations.text: The military officers all said: "Good."

sentences.zh: 項羽乃與期洹水南殷虛上。

translations.text: Xiang Yu then made an appointment at Yin Ruins south of the Huan River.

sentences.zh: 已盟，章邯見項羽而流涕，為言趙高。

translations.text: Having sworn the oath, Zhang Han saw Xiang Yu and wept, explaining about Zhao Gao.

sentences.zh: 項羽乃立章邯為雍王，置楚軍中。

translations.text: Xiang Yu then installed Zhang Han as King of Yong and kept him in the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 使長史欣為上將軍，將秦軍為前行。

translations.text: He made Chief Clerk Xin supreme general to lead the Qin army as vanguard.

Zhang Han sent men to see Xiang Yu, seeking an agreement. Xiang Yu summoned his military officers to deliberate, saying: "Grain is scarce; I wish to accept their agreement." The military officers all said: "Good." Xiang Yu then made an appointment at Yin Ruins south of the Huan River. Having sworn the oath, Zhang Han saw Xiang Yu and wept, explaining about Zhao Gao. Xiang Yu then installed Zhang Han as King of Yong and kept him in the Chu army. He made Chief Clerk Xin supreme general to lead the Qin army as vanguard.

sentences.zh: 到新安。

translations.text: They reached Xin'an.

sentences.zh: 諸侯吏卒異時故繇使屯戍過秦中，秦中吏卒遇之多無狀，及秦軍降諸侯，諸侯吏卒乘勝多奴虜使之，輕折辱秦吏卒。

translations.text: The feudal lords' officers and troops at different times had previously been sent on corvée duty to garrison passes through Qin territory; Qin officers and troops had treated them mostly without propriety, and when the Qin army surrendered to the feudal lords, the feudal lords' officers and troops, riding their victory, mostly enslaved and used them, lightly abusing and humiliating Qin officers and troops.

sentences.zh: 秦吏卒多竊言曰：「章將軍等詐吾屬降諸侯，今能入關破秦，大善；

translations.text: Many Qin officers and troops secretly said: "General Zhang and others deceived us into surrendering to the feudal lords; now if we can enter the passes and break Qin, very good;

sentences.zh: 即不能，諸侯虜吾屬而東，秦必盡誅吾父母妻子。」

translations.text: but if we cannot, the feudal lords will capture us and go east, and Qin will certainly execute all our fathers, mothers, wives, and children."

sentences.zh: 諸侯微聞其計，以告項羽。

translations.text: The feudal lords faintly heard their plotting and informed Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 項羽乃召黥布、蒲將軍計曰：「秦吏卒尚眾，其心不服，至關中不聽，事必危，不如擊殺之，而獨與章邯、長史欣、都尉翳入秦。」

translations.text: Xiang Yu then summoned Qing Bu and General Pu to deliberate, saying: "The Qin officers and troops are still numerous and their hearts are not submissive; when we reach Guanzhong if they do not obey, the situation will certainly be dangerous; it would be better to strike and kill them, and go into Qin only with Zhang Han, Chief Clerk Xin, and Commandant Yi."

sentences.zh: 於是楚軍夜擊阬秦卒二十餘萬人新安城南。

translations.text: Thereupon the Chu army by night attacked and buried alive over two hundred thousand Qin troops south of Xin'an city.

They reached Xin'an. The feudal lords' officers and troops at different times had previously been sent on corvée duty to garrison passes through Qin territory; Qin officers and troops had treated them mostly without propriety, and when the Qin army surrendered to the feudal lords, the feudal lords' officers and troops, riding their victory, mostly enslaved and used them, lightly abusing and humiliating Qin officers and troops. Many Qin officers and troops secretly said: "General Zhang and others deceived us into surrendering to the feudal lords; now if we can enter the passes and break Qin, very good; but if we cannot, the feudal lords will capture us and go east, and Qin will certainly execute all our fathers, mothers, wives, and children." The feudal lords faintly heard their plotting and informed Xiang Yu. Xiang Yu then summoned Qing Bu and General Pu to deliberate, saying: "The Qin officers and troops are still numerous and their hearts are not submissive; when we reach Guanzhong if they do not obey, the situation will certainly be dangerous; it would be better to strike and kill them, and go into Qin only with Zhang Han, Chief Clerk Xin, and Commandant Yi." Thereupon the Chu army by night attacked and buried alive over two hundred thousand Qin troops south of Xin'an city.

sentences.zh: 行略定秦地。

translations.text: [Xiang Yu's troops] came to Hangu Pass in former Qin territory.

sentences.zh: 函谷關有兵守關，不得入。

translations.text: The pass was guarded by (Liu Bang's) soldiers so [Xiang Yu] could not get through.

sentences.zh: 又聞沛公已破咸陽，項羽大怒，使當陽君等擊關。

translations.text: Apart from this, it was said that Pei Gong (namely Liu Bang) had already occupied Xian Yang city.

sentences.zh: 項羽遂入，至于戲西。

translations.text: Xiang Yu hence got fiercely angry, so he ordered Lord Dang Yang to attack the pass.

sentences.zh: 沛公軍霸上，未得與項羽相見。

translations.text: Then he got through the pass and marched to Xixi.

sentences.zh: 沛公左司馬曹無傷使人言於項羽曰：「沛公欲王關中，使子嬰為相，珍寶盡有之。」

translations.text: Pei Gong's troops were stationed in Bashang; he did not have the chance to meet Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 項羽大怒，曰：「旦日饗士卒，為擊破沛公軍！」

translations.text: A military officer of Pei Gong, Cao Wushang, secretly sent a messenger to Xiang Yu, saying: "Pei Gong intends to be king of Guanzhong, with Zi Ying as prime minister, and possess all the treasures of Qin." Xiang Yu broke out in a rage, and said: "Prepare my soldiers tomorrow morning.

sentences.zh: 當是時，項羽兵四十萬，在新豐鴻門，沛公兵十萬，在霸上。

translations.text: I will destroy Pei Gong's army!" At that time, Xiang Yu had 400,000 men stationed in Hongmen, Pei Gong had 100,000 men in Bashang.

sentences.zh: 范增說項羽曰：「沛公居山東時，貪於財貨，好美姬。

translations.text: Fan Zeng said to Xiang Yu: "When Pei Gong was in Shandong, he was very greedy for treasures and beauties.

sentences.zh: 今入關，財物無所取，婦女無所幸，此其志不在小。

translations.text: But today in Guanzhong, treasures are untouched, women are intact.

sentences.zh: 吾令人望其氣，皆為龍虎，成五采，此天子氣也。

translations.text: This reveals his tremendous ambition.

sentences.zh: 急擊勿失。」

translations.text: I had his Qi observed, and it is like dragon and tiger, in five colors - this is the Qi of the Son of Heaven.

[Xiang Yu's troops] came to Hangu Pass in former Qin territory. The pass was guarded by (Liu Bang's) soldiers so [Xiang Yu] could not get through. Apart from this, it was said that Pei Gong (namely Liu Bang) had already occupied Xian Yang city. Xiang Yu hence got fiercely angry, so he ordered Lord Dang Yang to attack the pass. Then he got through the pass and marched to Xixi. Pei Gong's troops were stationed in Bashang; he did not have the chance to meet Xiang Yu. A military officer of Pei Gong, Cao Wushang, secretly sent a messenger to Xiang Yu, saying: "Pei Gong intends to be king of Guanzhong, with Zi Ying as prime minister, and possess all the treasures of Qin." Xiang Yu broke out in a rage, and said: "Prepare my soldiers tomorrow morning. I will destroy Pei Gong's army!" At that time, Xiang Yu had 400,000 men stationed in Hongmen, Pei Gong had 100,000 men in Bashang. Fan Zeng said to Xiang Yu: "When Pei Gong was in Shandong, he was very greedy for treasures and beauties. But today in Guanzhong, treasures are untouched, women are intact. This reveals his tremendous ambition. I had his Qi observed, and it is like dragon and tiger, in five colors - this is the Qi of the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 楚左尹項伯者，項羽季父也，素善留侯張良。

translations.text: Chu's Chief Minister of the Left Xiang Bo,

sentences.zh: 張良是時從沛公，項伯乃夜馳之沛公軍，私見張良，具告以事，欲呼張良與俱去。

translations.text: Xiang Yu's uncle,

sentences.zh: 曰：「毋從俱死也。」

translations.text: was a friend of Zhang Liang,

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「臣為韓王送沛公，沛公今事有急，亡去不義，不可不語。」

translations.text: Marquis of Liu.

sentences.zh: 良乃入，具告沛公。

translations.text: Zhang Liang worked for Pei Gong at the time.

sentences.zh: 沛公大驚，曰：「為之柰何？」

translations.text: Xiang Bo hence rode to Pei Gong's camp under the cover of the night,

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「誰為大王為此計者？」

translations.text: met Zhang Liang privately,

sentences.zh: 曰：「鯫生說我曰『距關，毋內諸侯，秦地可盡王也』。

translations.text: told him about the assault and asked him to escape,

sentences.zh: 故聽之。」

translations.text: saying: "You will die if you stay." Liang said: "I was appointed as Pei Gong's servant by the king of Han.

sentences.zh: 良曰：「料大王士卒足以當項王乎？」

translations.text: Now that Pei Gong is in danger,

sentences.zh: 沛公默然，曰：「固不如也，且為之柰何？」

translations.text: it is not justifiable for me to escape.

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「請往謂項伯，言沛公不敢背項王也。」

translations.text: I have to warn him."

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「君安與項伯有故？」

translations.text: Pei Gong said: "How do you have a connection with Xiang Bo?"

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「秦時與臣游，項伯殺人，臣活之。

translations.text: Zhang Liang said: "In Qin times he traveled with me; Xiang Bo killed a man and I saved his life.

sentences.zh: 今事有急，故幸來告良。」

translations.text: Now affairs are urgent, so he was fortunate to come inform Liang."

sentences.zh: 沛公曰「孰與君少長？」

translations.text: Pei Gong said: "Who is older, you or he?"

sentences.zh: 良曰：「長於臣。」

translations.text: Liang said: "He is older than me."

sentences.zh: 沛公曰「君為我呼入，吾得兄事之。」

translations.text: Pei Gong said: "Call him in for me; I can treat him as an elder brother."

sentences.zh: 張良出，要項伯。

translations.text: Zhang Liang went out and invited Xiang Bo.

sentences.zh: 項伯即入見沛公。

translations.text: Xiang Bo then entered to see Pei Gong.

sentences.zh: 沛公奉卮酒為壽，約為婚姻，曰：「吾入關，秋豪不敢有所近，籍吏民，封府庫，而待將軍。

translations.text: Pei Gong presented a cup of wine for a toast, made an agreement of marriage alliance, and said: "When I entered the passes, I did not dare touch even the slightest thing; I registered the officials and people, sealed the treasuries, and waited for the general.

sentences.zh: 所以遣將守關者，備他盜之出入與非常也。

translations.text: The reason I dispatched generals to guard the passes was to prepare against other bandits entering and exiting and extraordinary events.

sentences.zh: 日夜望將軍至，豈敢反乎！

translations.text: Day and night I awaited the general's arrival—how would I dare rebel!

sentences.zh: 願伯具言臣之不敢倍德也。」

translations.text: I hope you will fully explain to him that I would not dare betray his kindness."

sentences.zh: 項伯許諾。

translations.text: Xiang Bo consented.

sentences.zh: 謂沛公曰：「旦日不可不蚤自來謝項王。」

translations.text: He said to Pei Gong: "Tomorrow you must come early yourself to apologize to King Xiang."

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「諾。」

translations.text: Pei Gong said: "Yes."

sentences.zh: 於是項伯復夜去，至軍中，具以沛公言報項王。

translations.text: Thereupon Xiang Bo departed again by night, reached the army, and fully reported Pei Gong's words to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 因言曰：「沛公不先破關中，公豈敢入乎？

translations.text: He consequently said: "If Pei Gong had not first broken through Guanzhong, how would you have dared enter?

sentences.zh: 今人有大功而擊之，不義也，不如因善遇之。」

translations.text: Now the man has great achievements yet you attack him—this is not righteous; it would be better to treat him well on this account."

sentences.zh: 項王許諾。

translations.text: King Xiang consented.

Chu's Chief Minister of the Left Xiang Bo, Xiang Yu's uncle, was a friend of Zhang Liang, Marquis of Liu. Zhang Liang worked for Pei Gong at the time. Xiang Bo hence rode to Pei Gong's camp under the cover of the night, met Zhang Liang privately, told him about the assault and asked him to escape, saying: "You will die if you stay." Liang said: "I was appointed as Pei Gong's servant by the king of Han. Now that Pei Gong is in danger, it is not justifiable for me to escape. I have to warn him." Pei Gong said: "How do you have a connection with Xiang Bo?" Zhang Liang said: "In Qin times he traveled with me; Xiang Bo killed a man and I saved his life. Now affairs are urgent, so he was fortunate to come inform Liang." Pei Gong said: "Who is older, you or he?" Liang said: "He is older than me." Pei Gong said: "Call him in for me; I can treat him as an elder brother." Zhang Liang went out and invited Xiang Bo. Xiang Bo then entered to see Pei Gong. Pei Gong presented a cup of wine for a toast, made an agreement of marriage alliance, and said: "When I entered the passes, I did not dare touch even the slightest thing; I registered the officials and people, sealed the treasuries, and waited for the general. The reason I dispatched generals to guard the passes was to prepare against other bandits entering and exiting and extraordinary events. Day and night I awaited the general's arrival—how would I dare rebel! I hope you will fully explain to him that I would not dare betray his kindness." Xiang Bo consented. He said to Pei Gong: "Tomorrow you must come early yourself to apologize to King Xiang." Pei Gong said: "Yes." Thereupon Xiang Bo departed again by night, reached the army, and fully reported Pei Gong's words to King Xiang. He consequently said: "If Pei Gong had not first broken through Guanzhong, how would you have dared enter? Now the man has great achievements yet you attack him—this is not righteous; it would be better to treat him well on this account." King Xiang consented.

sentences.zh: 沛公旦日從百餘騎來見項王，至鴻門，謝曰：「臣與將軍戮力而攻秦，將軍戰河北，臣戰河南，然不自意能先入關破秦，得復見將軍於此。

translations.text: The second day,

sentences.zh: 今者有小人之言，令將軍與臣有郤。」

translations.text: accompanied by one hundred cavalrymen,

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「此沛公左司馬曹無傷言之；

translations.text: Pei Gong came to meet King Xiang in Hongmen.

sentences.zh: 不然，籍何以至此。」

translations.text: Pei Gong apologized: "The general and I fought side by side against Qin.

sentences.zh: 項王即日因留沛公與飲。

translations.text: The general fought on the northern side of the (Yellow) river,

sentences.zh: 項王、項伯東向坐。

translations.text: and I fought on the south.

sentences.zh: 亞父南向坐。

translations.text: I did not expect that I could be the first to break into Guanzhong and defeat Qin,

sentences.zh: 亞父者，范增也。

translations.text: and finally meet the general here.

sentences.zh: 沛公北向坐，張良西向侍。

translations.text: There must be a petty man trying to casts a bone between the general and me." King Xiang said: "This is all because of your officer Cao Wushang,

sentences.zh: 范增數目項王，舉所佩玉珪以示之者三，項王默然不應。

translations.text: otherwise I would not have done this."

sentences.zh: 范增起，出召項莊，謂曰：「君王為人不忍，若入前為壽，壽畢，請以劍舞，因擊沛公於坐，殺之。

translations.text: Fan Zeng rose, went out and summoned Xiang Zhuang, saying: "The king is too soft-hearted; if you go in to offer a toast, when the toast is finished, request to perform a sword dance, and take the opportunity to strike Pei Gong where he sits and kill him.

sentences.zh: 不者，若屬皆且為所虜。」

translations.text: If not, you and your kind will all become his captives."

sentences.zh: 莊則入為壽，壽畢，曰：「君王與沛公飲，軍中無以為樂，請以劍舞。」

translations.text: Zhuang then entered to offer a toast; when the toast was finished, he said: "The king and Pei Gong are drinking; in the army there is no way to make merry—I request to perform a sword dance."

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「諾。」

translations.text: King Xiang said: "Very well."

sentences.zh: 項莊拔劍起舞，項伯亦拔劍起舞，常以身翼蔽沛公，莊不得擊。

translations.text: Xiang Zhuang drew his sword and rose to dance; Xiang Bo also drew his sword and rose to dance, constantly using his body to shield Pei Gong with his wings, so Zhuang could not strike.

sentences.zh: 於是張良至軍門，見樊噲。

translations.text: Thereupon Zhang Liang went to the army gate and saw Fan Kuai.

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「今日之事何如？」

translations.text: Fan Kuai said: "How go today's affairs?"

sentences.zh: 良曰：「甚急。

translations.text: Liang said: "Very urgent.

sentences.zh: 今者項莊拔劍舞，其意常在沛公也。」

translations.text: Right now Xiang Zhuang is performing a sword dance, but his intent is always on Pei Gong."

sentences.zh: 噲曰：「此迫矣，臣請入，與之同命。」

translations.text: Kuai said: "This is pressing; I request to enter and share his fate."

sentences.zh: 噲即帶劍擁盾入軍門。

translations.text: Kuai then wore his sword, grasped his shield, and entered the army gate.

sentences.zh: 交戟之衛士欲止不內，樊噲側其盾以撞，衛士仆地，噲遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目視項王，頭髪上指，目眥盡裂。

translations.text: The guards with crossed halberds wished to stop him from entering; Fan Kuai turned his shield sideways to ram them, the guards fell to the ground, Kuai then entered, pushed aside the curtain and stood facing west, glaring at King Xiang, his hair standing on end and the corners of his eyes splitting open.

sentences.zh: 項王按劍而跽曰：「客何為者？」

translations.text: King Xiang pressed his hand on his sword and knelt upright, saying: "Who is this stranger?"

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「沛公之參乘樊噲者也。」

translations.text: Zhang Liang said: "This is Pei Gong's bodyguard Fan Kuai."

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「壯士，賜之卮酒。」

translations.text: King Xiang said: "A brave man! Give him a cup of wine."

sentences.zh: 則與斗卮酒。

translations.text: They then gave him a dou-measure cup of wine.

sentences.zh: 噲拜謝，起，立而飲之。

translations.text: Kuai bowed in thanks, rose, and drank it standing.

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「賜之彘肩。」

translations.text: King Xiang said: "Give him a pork shoulder."

sentences.zh: 則與一生彘肩。

translations.text: They then gave him a raw pork shoulder.

sentences.zh: 樊噲覆其盾於地，加彘肩上，拔劍切而啗之。

translations.text: Fan Kuai placed his shield on the ground, put the pork shoulder on top, drew his sword, sliced it, and devoured it.

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「壯士，能復飲乎？」

translations.text: King Xiang said: "Brave man, can you drink more?"

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「臣死且不避，卮酒安足辭！

translations.text: Fan Kuai said: "I do not even avoid death—why would a cup of wine be worth declining!

sentences.zh: 夫秦王有虎狼之心，殺人如不能舉，刑人如恐不勝，天下皆叛之。

translations.text: The King of Qin had the heart of a tiger and wolf; he killed men as if unable to finish, punished men as if fearing he could not prevail; the entire world rebelled against him.

sentences.zh: 懷王與諸將約曰『先破秦入咸陽者王之』。

translations.text: King Huai made an agreement with the generals saying 'He who first breaks through Qin and enters Xianyang shall be its king.'

sentences.zh: 今沛公先破秦入咸陽，豪毛不敢有所近，封閉宮室，還軍霸上，以待大王來。

translations.text: Now Pei Gong first broke through Qin and entered Xianyang; he did not dare touch even the slightest hair, sealed and closed the palace chambers, returned his army to Bashang, and waited for the great king to arrive.

sentences.zh: 故遣將守關者，備他盜出入與非常也。

translations.text: The reason he dispatched generals to guard the passes was to prepare against other bandits entering and exiting and extraordinary events.

sentences.zh: 勞苦而功高如此，未有封侯之賞，而聽細說，欲誅有功之人。

translations.text: His toil and suffering with achievements so high—yet there has been no reward of enfeoffment as a marquis, and instead you listen to petty slander wishing to execute someone with achievements.

sentences.zh: 此亡秦之續耳，竊為大王不取也。」

translations.text: This is merely continuing the Qin's path to destruction; I secretly believe the great king should not take it."

sentences.zh: 項王未有以應，曰：「坐。」

translations.text: King Xiang had no response and said: "Sit."

sentences.zh: 樊噲從良坐。

translations.text: Fan Kuai sat with Liang.

sentences.zh: 坐須臾，沛公起如廁，因招樊噲出。

translations.text: After sitting briefly, Pei Gong rose as if to use the privy and beckoned Fan Kuai to come out.

The second day, accompanied by one hundred cavalrymen, Pei Gong came to meet King Xiang in Hongmen. Pei Gong apologized: "The general and I fought side by side against Qin. The general fought on the northern side of the (Yellow) river, and I fought on the south. I did not expect that I could be the first to break into Guanzhong and defeat Qin, and finally meet the general here. There must be a petty man trying to casts a bone between the general and me." King Xiang said: "This is all because of your officer Cao Wushang, otherwise I would not have done this." Fan Zeng rose, went out and summoned Xiang Zhuang, saying: "The king is too soft-hearted; if you go in to offer a toast, when the toast is finished, request to perform a sword dance, and take the opportunity to strike Pei Gong where he sits and kill him. If not, you and your kind will all become his captives." Zhuang then entered to offer a toast; when the toast was finished, he said: "The king and Pei Gong are drinking; in the army there is no way to make merry—I request to perform a sword dance." King Xiang said: "Very well." Xiang Zhuang drew his sword and rose to dance; Xiang Bo also drew his sword and rose to dance, constantly using his body to shield Pei Gong with his wings, so Zhuang could not strike. Thereupon Zhang Liang went to the army gate and saw Fan Kuai. Fan Kuai said: "How go today's affairs?" Liang said: "Very urgent. Right now Xiang Zhuang is performing a sword dance, but his intent is always on Pei Gong." Kuai said: "This is pressing; I request to enter and share his fate." Kuai then wore his sword, grasped his shield, and entered the army gate. The guards with crossed halberds wished to stop him from entering; Fan Kuai turned his shield sideways to ram them, the guards fell to the ground, Kuai then entered, pushed aside the curtain and stood facing west, glaring at King Xiang, his hair standing on end and the corners of his eyes splitting open. King Xiang pressed his hand on his sword and knelt upright, saying: "Who is this stranger?" Zhang Liang said: "This is Pei Gong's bodyguard Fan Kuai." King Xiang said: "A brave man! Give him a cup of wine." They then gave him a dou-measure cup of wine. Kuai bowed in thanks, rose, and drank it standing. King Xiang said: "Give him a pork shoulder." They then gave him a raw pork shoulder. Fan Kuai placed his shield on the ground, put the pork shoulder on top, drew his sword, sliced it, and devoured it. King Xiang said: "Brave man, can you drink more?" Fan Kuai said: "I do not even avoid death—why would a cup of wine be worth declining! The King of Qin had the heart of a tiger and wolf; he killed men as if unable to finish, punished men as if fearing he could not prevail; the entire world rebelled against him. King Huai made an agreement with the generals saying 'He who first breaks through Qin and enters Xianyang shall be its king.' Now Pei Gong first broke through Qin and entered Xianyang; he did not dare touch even the slightest hair, sealed and closed the palace chambers, returned his army to Bashang, and waited for the great king to arrive. The reason he dispatched generals to guard the passes was to prepare against other bandits entering and exiting and extraordinary events. His toil and suffering with achievements so high—yet there has been no reward of enfeoffment as a marquis, and instead you listen to petty slander wishing to execute someone with achievements. This is merely continuing the Qin's path to destruction; I secretly believe the great king should not take it." King Xiang had no response and said: "Sit." Fan Kuai sat with Liang. After sitting briefly, Pei Gong rose as if to use the privy and beckoned Fan Kuai to come out.

sentences.zh: 沛公已出，項王使都尉陳平召沛公。

translations.text: As Pei Gong has come out,

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「今者出，未辭也，為之柰何？」

translations.text: King Xiang ordered Lieutenant Chen Ping to call him back in.

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「大行不顧細謹，大禮不辭小讓。

translations.text: Pei Gong said (to Fan Kuai): "I came out without saying goodbye,

sentences.zh: 如今人方為刀俎，我為魚肉，何辭為。」

translations.text: what should I do now?" Fan Kuai said: "The most powerful never mind small matters;

sentences.zh: 於是遂去。

translations.text: the most polite never care about small etiquette.

sentences.zh: 乃令張良留謝。

translations.text: Now they are knife and chopping block,

sentences.zh: 良問曰：「大王來何操？」

translations.text: we are fish in between,

sentences.zh: 曰：「我持白璧一雙，欲獻項王，玉斗一雙，欲與亞父，會其怒，不敢獻。

translations.text: why need we say goodbye?" So [Pei Gong decided to] leave.

sentences.zh: 公為我獻之」張良曰：「謹諾。」

translations.text: He ordered Zhang Liang to stay and apologize for him.

sentences.zh: 當是時，項王軍在鴻門下，沛公軍在霸上，相去四十里。

translations.text: Liang asked: "Have you brought anything here?" [Pei Gong] said: "I have a pair of white jade for the Lord,

sentences.zh: 沛公則置車騎，脫身獨騎，與樊噲、夏侯嬰、靳彊、紀信等四人持劍盾步走，從酈山下，道芷陽閒行。

translations.text: and a pair of jade pecks for Yafu.

sentences.zh: 沛公謂張良曰：「從此道至吾軍，不過二十里耳。

translations.text: They were angry so I dare not give them.

sentences.zh: 度我至軍中，公乃入。」

translations.text: Please deliver the gifts for me." Liang said: "Yes."

sentences.zh: 沛公已去，閒至軍中，張良入謝，曰：「沛公不勝桮杓，不能辭。

translations.text: After Pei Gong had left and stolen away to reach the army, Zhang Liang entered to apologize, saying: "Pei Gong cannot hold his wine and is unable to take leave.

sentences.zh: 謹使臣良奉白璧一雙，再拜獻大王足下；

translations.text: He has respectfully sent me, Liang, with a pair of white jade disks, to bow twice and present them at the great king's feet;

sentences.zh: 玉斗一雙，再拜奉大將軍足下。」

translations.text: and a pair of jade dippers, to bow twice and offer them at the Supreme General's feet."

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「沛公安在？」

translations.text: King Xiang said: "Where is Pei Gong?"

sentences.zh: 良曰：「聞大王有意督過之，脫身獨去，已至軍矣。」

translations.text: Liang said: "Hearing the great king intended to reproach and censure him, he escaped alone and has already reached his army."

sentences.zh: 項王則受璧，置之坐上。

translations.text: King Xiang then accepted the disks and placed them on his seat.

sentences.zh: 亞父受玉斗，置之地，拔劍撞而破之，曰：「唉！

translations.text: The Second Father accepted the jade dippers, placed them on the ground, drew his sword, struck and shattered them, saying: "Alas!

sentences.zh: 豎子不足與謀。

translations.text: This youngster is not worth plotting with.

sentences.zh: 奪項王天下者，必沛公也，吾屬今為之虜矣。」

translations.text: He who seizes all under Heaven from King Xiang will certainly be Pei Gong; we will now become his captives."

sentences.zh: 沛公至軍，立誅殺曹無傷。

translations.text: When Pei Gong reached his army, he immediately executed Cao Wushang.

As Pei Gong has come out, King Xiang ordered Lieutenant Chen Ping to call him back in. Pei Gong said (to Fan Kuai): "I came out without saying goodbye, what should I do now?" Fan Kuai said: "The most powerful never mind small matters; the most polite never care about small etiquette. Now they are knife and chopping block, we are fish in between, why need we say goodbye?" So [Pei Gong decided to] leave. He ordered Zhang Liang to stay and apologize for him. Liang asked: "Have you brought anything here?" [Pei Gong] said: "I have a pair of white jade for the Lord, and a pair of jade pecks for Yafu. They were angry so I dare not give them. Please deliver the gifts for me." Liang said: "Yes." After Pei Gong had left and stolen away to reach the army, Zhang Liang entered to apologize, saying: "Pei Gong cannot hold his wine and is unable to take leave. He has respectfully sent me, Liang, with a pair of white jade disks, to bow twice and present them at the great king's feet; and a pair of jade dippers, to bow twice and offer them at the Supreme General's feet." King Xiang said: "Where is Pei Gong?" Liang said: "Hearing the great king intended to reproach and censure him, he escaped alone and has already reached his army." King Xiang then accepted the disks and placed them on his seat. The Second Father accepted the jade dippers, placed them on the ground, drew his sword, struck and shattered them, saying: "Alas! This youngster is not worth plotting with. He who seizes all under Heaven from King Xiang will certainly be Pei Gong; we will now become his captives." When Pei Gong reached his army, he immediately executed Cao Wushang.

sentences.zh: 居數日，項羽引兵西屠咸陽，殺秦降王子嬰，燒秦宮室，火三月不滅；

translations.text: After several days, Xiang Yu led his troops west, massacred Xianyang, killed the surrendered King of Qin, Ziying, burned the Qin palace chambers—the fire did not go out for three months;

sentences.zh: 收其貨寶婦女而東。

translations.text: collected their wealth, treasures, and women, and went east.

sentences.zh: 人或說項王曰：「關中阻山河四塞，地肥饒，可都以霸。」

translations.text: Someone persuaded King Xiang, saying: "Guanzhong is protected by mountains and rivers on four sides; the land is fertile and rich—you could make it your capital to establish hegemony."

sentences.zh: 項王見秦宮皆以燒殘破，又心懷思欲東歸，曰：「富貴不歸故鄉，如衣繡夜行，誰知之者！」

translations.text: King Xiang saw that the Qin palaces had all been burned and ruined, and in his heart he longed to return east, saying: "Wealth and honor without returning to one's native place is like wearing embroidered robes at night—who would know it!"

sentences.zh: 說者曰：「人言楚人沐猴而冠耳，果然。」

translations.text: The persuader said: "People say the Chu are macaques wearing caps—it turns out to be true."

sentences.zh: 項王聞之，烹說者。

translations.text: King Xiang, hearing this, boiled the persuader alive.

After several days, Xiang Yu led his troops west, massacred Xianyang, killed the surrendered King of Qin, Ziying, burned the Qin palace chambers—the fire did not go out for three months; collected their wealth, treasures, and women, and went east. Someone persuaded King Xiang, saying: "Guanzhong is protected by mountains and rivers on four sides; the land is fertile and rich—you could make it your capital to establish hegemony." King Xiang saw that the Qin palaces had all been burned and ruined, and in his heart he longed to return east, saying: "Wealth and honor without returning to one's native place is like wearing embroidered robes at night—who would know it!" The persuader said: "People say the Chu are macaques wearing caps—it turns out to be true." King Xiang, hearing this, boiled the persuader alive.

sentences.zh: 項王使人致命懷王。

translations.text: King Xiang sent men to present orders to King Huai.

sentences.zh: 懷王曰：「如約。」
