translations.text: King Huai said: "According to the agreement."

sentences.zh: 乃尊懷王為義帝。

translations.text: They then honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor.

sentences.zh: 項王欲自王，先王諸將相。

translations.text: King Xiang wished to make himself king and first made the generals and ministers kings.

sentences.zh: 謂曰：「天下初發難時，假立諸侯後以伐秦。

translations.text: He said: "When all under Heaven first raised difficulties, we provisionally installed descendants of feudal lords to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 然身被堅執銳首事，暴露於野三年，滅秦定天下者，皆將相諸君與籍之力也。

translations.text: Yet I personally wore armor and wielded sharp weapons to initiate affairs, exposed in the wilderness for three years; those who destroyed Qin and settled all under Heaven were all you generals, ministers, and lords together with Ji's strength.

sentences.zh: 義帝雖無功，故當分其地而王之。」

translations.text: Though the Righteous Emperor had no achievements, he should still be given his share of territory to rule."

sentences.zh: 諸將皆曰：「善。」

translations.text: All the generals said: "Excellent."

sentences.zh: 乃分天下，立諸將為侯王。

translations.text: He then divided all under Heaven and installed the generals as marquis-kings.

sentences.zh: 項王、范增疑沛公之有天下，業已講解，又惡負約，恐諸侯叛之，乃陰謀曰：「巴、蜀道險，秦之遷人皆居蜀。」

translations.text: King Xiang and Fan Zeng suspected Pei Gong of having designs on all under Heaven; affairs had already been reconciled, yet they were reluctant to break the agreement and feared the feudal lords would rebel; so they secretly plotted, saying: "The roads of Ba and Shu are treacherous; the Qin people who were exiled all reside in Shu."

sentences.zh: 乃曰：「巴、蜀亦關中地也。」

translations.text: They then said: "Ba and Shu are also Guanzhong territory."

sentences.zh: 故立沛公為漢王，王巴、蜀、漢中，都南鄭。

translations.text: Therefore they installed Pei Gong as King of Han, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng.

sentences.zh: 而三分關中，王秦降將以距塞漢王。

translations.text: They divided Guanzhong into three parts, making kings of the surrendered Qin generals to block the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 項王乃立章邯為雍王，王咸陽以西，都廢丘。

translations.text: King Xiang then installed Zhang Han as King of Yong, ruling west of Xianyang, with his capital at Feiqiu.

sentences.zh: 長史欣者，故為櫟陽獄掾，嘗有德於項梁；

translations.text: Chief Clerk Xin had formerly been a prison clerk at Liyang and once had shown kindness to Xiang Liang;

sentences.zh: 都尉董翳者，本勸章邯降楚。

translations.text: Commandant Dong Yi had originally urged Zhang Han to surrender to Chu.

sentences.zh: 故立司馬欣為塞王，王咸陽以東至河，都櫟陽；

translations.text: Therefore he installed Sima Xin as King of Sai, ruling from east of Xianyang to the Yellow River, with his capital at Liyang;

sentences.zh: 立董翳為翟王，王上郡，都高奴。

translations.text: installed Dong Yi as King of Di, ruling Shangjun, with his capital at Gaonu.

sentences.zh: 徙魏王豹為西魏王，王河東，都平陽。

translations.text: He moved King Bao of Wei to be King of Western Wei, ruling Hedong, with his capital at Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 瑕丘申陽者，張耳嬖臣也，先下河南（郡），迎楚河上，故立申陽為河南王，都雒陽。

translations.text: Shen Yang of Xiaqiu was a favorite minister of Zhang Er; he had first taken Henan Commandery and welcomed Chu at the Yellow River, so they installed Shen Yang as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 韓王成因故都，都陽翟。

translations.text: King Cheng of Han retained his former capital, with his capital at Yangzhai.

sentences.zh: 趙將司馬卬定河內，數有功，故立卬為殷王，王河內，都朝歌。

translations.text: Zhao general Sima Ang had pacified Henei and repeatedly achieved merit, so they installed Ang as King of Yin, ruling Henei, with his capital at Chaoge.

sentences.zh: 徙趙王歇為代王。

translations.text: They moved King Xie of Zhao to be King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 趙相張耳素賢，又從入關，故立耳為常山王，王趙地，都襄國。

translations.text: Zhao's Prime Minister Zhang Er had always been worthy and also followed them into the passes, so they installed Er as King of Changshan, ruling Zhao territory, with his capital at Xiangguo.

sentences.zh: 當陽君黥布為楚將，常冠軍，故立布為九江王，都六。

translations.text: Lord Dangyang Qing Bu as Chu general had always been foremost, so they installed Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu.

sentences.zh: 鄱君吳芮率百越佐諸侯，又從入關，故立芮為衡山王，都邾。

translations.text: Lord Po Wu Rui led the Hundred Yue to assist the feudal lords and also followed them into the passes, so they installed Rui as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu.

sentences.zh: 義帝柱國共敖將兵擊南郡，功多，因立敖為臨江王，都江陵。

translations.text: The Righteous Emperor's Supreme Pillar of State Gong Ao led troops to attack Nanjun with many achievements, so they installed Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling.

sentences.zh: 徙燕王韓廣為遼東王。

translations.text: They moved King Han Guang of Yan to be King of Liaodong.

sentences.zh: 燕將臧荼從楚救趙，因從入關，故立荼為燕王，都薊。

translations.text: Yan general Zang Tu followed Chu to rescue Zhao and consequently followed them into the passes, so they installed Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji.

sentences.zh: 徙齊王田市為膠東王。

translations.text: They moved King Tian Shi of Qi to be King of Jiaodong.

sentences.zh: 齊將田都從共救趙，因從入關，故立都為齊王，都臨菑。

translations.text: Qi general Tian Du followed together to rescue Zhao and consequently followed them into the passes, so they installed Du as King of Qi, with his capital at Linzi.

sentences.zh: 故秦所滅齊王建孫田安，項羽方渡河救趙，田安下濟北數城，引其兵降項羽，故立安為濟北王，都博陽。

translations.text: Tian An, grandson of King Jian of Qi whom Qin had destroyed—when Xiang Yu was crossing the Yellow River to rescue Zhao, Tian An took several cities in Jibei and led his troops to surrender to Xiang Yu, so they installed An as King of Jibei, with his capital at Boyang.

sentences.zh: 田榮者，數負項梁，又不肯將兵從楚擊秦，以故不封。

translations.text: Thus the feudal lords were all enfeoffed; they all went to their states.

sentences.zh: 成安君陳餘棄將印去，不從入關，然素聞其賢，有功於趙，聞其在南皮，故因環封三縣。

translations.text: King Huai of Chu, the Righteous Emperor, was without territory.

sentences.zh: 番君將梅鋗功多，故封十萬戶侯。

translations.text: In the tenth month, King Xiang of Chu left Xiang Yu to go to Pengcheng, killed Tian An of Jibei, made his state part of Chu.

sentences.zh: 項王自立為西楚霸王，王九郡，都彭城。

translations.text: In the first month, he made an announcement saying: "The Righteous Emperor has no descendants."

King Xiang sent men to present orders to King Huai. King Huai said: "According to the agreement." They then honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor. King Xiang wished to make himself king and first made the generals and ministers kings. He said: "When all under Heaven first raised difficulties, we provisionally installed descendants of feudal lords to attack Qin. Yet I personally wore armor and wielded sharp weapons to initiate affairs, exposed in the wilderness for three years; those who destroyed Qin and settled all under Heaven were all you generals, ministers, and lords together with Ji's strength. Though the Righteous Emperor had no achievements, he should still be given his share of territory to rule." All the generals said: "Excellent." He then divided all under Heaven and installed the generals as marquis-kings. King Xiang and Fan Zeng suspected Pei Gong of having designs on all under Heaven; affairs had already been reconciled, yet they were reluctant to break the agreement and feared the feudal lords would rebel; so they secretly plotted, saying: "The roads of Ba and Shu are treacherous; the Qin people who were exiled all reside in Shu." They then said: "Ba and Shu are also Guanzhong territory." Therefore they installed Pei Gong as King of Han, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng. They divided Guanzhong into three parts, making kings of the surrendered Qin generals to block the King of Han. King Xiang then installed Zhang Han as King of Yong, ruling west of Xianyang, with his capital at Feiqiu. Chief Clerk Xin had formerly been a prison clerk at Liyang and once had shown kindness to Xiang Liang; Commandant Dong Yi had originally urged Zhang Han to surrender to Chu. Therefore he installed Sima Xin as King of Sai, ruling from east of Xianyang to the Yellow River, with his capital at Liyang; installed Dong Yi as King of Di, ruling Shangjun, with his capital at Gaonu. He moved King Bao of Wei to be King of Western Wei, ruling Hedong, with his capital at Pingyang. Shen Yang of Xiaqiu was a favorite minister of Zhang Er; he had first taken Henan Commandery and welcomed Chu at the Yellow River, so they installed Shen Yang as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang. King Cheng of Han retained his former capital, with his capital at Yangzhai. Zhao general Sima Ang had pacified Henei and repeatedly achieved merit, so they installed Ang as King of Yin, ruling Henei, with his capital at Chaoge. They moved King Xie of Zhao to be King of Dai. Zhao's Prime Minister Zhang Er had always been worthy and also followed them into the passes, so they installed Er as King of Changshan, ruling Zhao territory, with his capital at Xiangguo. Lord Dangyang Qing Bu as Chu general had always been foremost, so they installed Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu. Lord Po Wu Rui led the Hundred Yue to assist the feudal lords and also followed them into the passes, so they installed Rui as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu. The Righteous Emperor's Supreme Pillar of State Gong Ao led troops to attack Nanjun with many achievements, so they installed Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling. They moved King Han Guang of Yan to be King of Liaodong. Yan general Zang Tu followed Chu to rescue Zhao and consequently followed them into the passes, so they installed Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji. They moved King Tian Shi of Qi to be King of Jiaodong. Qi general Tian Du followed together to rescue Zhao and consequently followed them into the passes, so they installed Du as King of Qi, with his capital at Linzi. Tian An, grandson of King Jian of Qi whom Qin had destroyed—when Xiang Yu was crossing the Yellow River to rescue Zhao, Tian An took several cities in Jibei and led his troops to surrender to Xiang Yu, so they installed An as King of Jibei, with his capital at Boyang. Thus the feudal lords were all enfeoffed; they all went to their states. King Huai of Chu, the Righteous Emperor, was without territory. In the tenth month, King Xiang of Chu left Xiang Yu to go to Pengcheng, killed Tian An of Jibei, made his state part of Chu. In the first month, he made an announcement saying: "The Righteous Emperor has no descendants."

sentences.zh: 漢之元年四月，諸侯罷戲下，各就國。

translations.text: He secretly ordered the kings of Hengshan and Linjiang to attack and kill the Righteous Emperor at Jiangzhong.

sentences.zh: 項王出之國，使人徙義帝，曰：「古之帝者地方千里，必居上游。」

translations.text: The King of Han heard that the Righteous Emperor had been killed, then mourned for him.

sentences.zh: 乃使使徙義帝長沙郴縣。

translations.text: When the feudal lords heard that the King of Han mourned the Righteous Emperor, they mostly rebelled against Chu and pledged allegiance to Han; the land of Qi and Zhao revolted several times.

sentences.zh: 趣義帝行，其群臣稍稍背叛之，乃陰令衡山、臨江王擊殺之江中。

translations.text: In the second month, the King of Han from his fief in Nanzheng went out and took his kingdom; the subordinate counties in the territory of Ba and Shu rallied to him.

sentences.zh: 韓王成無軍功，項王不使之國，與俱至彭城，廢以為侯，已又殺之。

translations.text: In the third month, he crossed Lin Jin in the north.

sentences.zh: 臧荼之國，因逐韓廣之遼東，廣弗聽，荼擊殺廣無終，

translations.text: In the fourth month, he reached Chencang, fixed roads and repaired bridges, blocked the old passage by burning.

He secretly ordered the kings of Hengshan and Linjiang to attack and kill the Righteous Emperor at Jiangzhong. The King of Han heard that the Righteous Emperor had been killed, then mourned for him. When the feudal lords heard that the King of Han mourned the Righteous Emperor, they mostly rebelled against Chu and pledged allegiance to Han; the land of Qi and Zhao revolted several times. In the second month, the King of Han from his fief in Nanzheng went out and took his kingdom; the subordinate counties in the territory of Ba and Shu rallied to him. In the third month, he crossed Lin Jin in the north. In the fourth month, he reached Chencang, fixed roads and repaired bridges, blocked the old passage by burning.

sentences.zh: 田榮聞項羽徙齊王市膠東，而立齊將田都為齊王，乃大怒，不肯遣齊王之膠東，因以齊反，迎擊田都。

translations.text: King Xiang sent troops to block the Triple Pass; none could pass through.

sentences.zh: 田都走楚。

translations.text: In the fifth month, King Han pacified the Three Qins; King Xiang heard this and was greatly enraged.

sentences.zh: 齊王市畏項王，乃亡之膠東就國。

translations.text: He sent Marquis of Jiujiang to attack Han; also sent soldiers to surround the King of Yan and Marquis of Yangxia.

sentences.zh: 田榮怒，追擊殺之即墨。

translations.text: Marquis of Yangxia fled to Han.

sentences.zh: 榮因自立為齊王，而西殺擊濟北王田安，并王三齊。

translations.text: He sent others to persuade the King of Qi to rebel against Han, and the King of Qi rebelled against Han and allied with Chu.

sentences.zh: 榮與彭越將軍印，令反梁地。

translations.text: King Xiang himself marched east to strike Qi.

sentences.zh: 陳餘陰使張同、夏說說齊王田榮曰：「項羽為天下宰，不平。

translations.text: He reached Chenyi where he heard that the King of Han had already occupied the three parts of Guanzhong and would attack Chu; King Xiang then returned to lead his troops north, killing Tian Rong.

sentences.zh: 今盡王故王於醜地，而王其群臣諸將善地，逐其故主趙王，乃北居代，餘以為不可。

translations.text: The King of Han went out to lead his troops to seize Pengcheng; King Xiang heard this and led his troops back to defeat the King of Han at Pengcheng, beheaded Marquis of Jiujiang, and the King of Han fled.

sentences.zh: 聞大王起兵，且不聽不義，願大王資餘兵，請以擊常山，以復趙王，請以國為捍蔽。」

translations.text: King Xiang then went north to strike the lands of Qi; all of Qi revolted to follow Tian Rong's younger brother Tian Heng as king.

sentences.zh: 齊王許之，因遣兵之趙。

translations.text: The King of Han gained possession of Lu, Liang, Chu, and Zhao, and sent envoys respectfully inviting the kings of the feudal lords to attack Chu together.

sentences.zh: 陳餘悉發三縣兵，與齊并力擊常山，大破之。

translations.text: In the fourth month of the third year of Han, King Xiang heard that the King of Han had occupied Pengcheng; King Xiang was then in Qi, riding day and night from Qi, engaging the Han army at Lu.

sentences.zh: 張耳走歸漢。

translations.text: The Han army had many soldiers, tens of thousands of people, and blocked the water's edge; the King of Chu constantly selected elite cavalry of three thousand, the Han army was completely defeated.

sentences.zh: 陳餘迎故趙王歇於代，反之趙。

translations.text: In the fourth month of that year, King Xiang went west through Lingbi, striking the troops of Han and the feudal lords, defeating them; Liang and Chu were pacified.

sentences.zh: 趙王因立陳餘為代王。

translations.text: The King of Han fled north, crossing the Sui River.

King Xiang sent troops to block the Triple Pass; none could pass through. In the fifth month, King Han pacified the Three Qins; King Xiang heard this and was greatly enraged. He sent Marquis of Jiujiang to attack Han; also sent soldiers to surround the King of Yan and Marquis of Yangxia. Marquis of Yangxia fled to Han. He sent others to persuade the King of Qi to rebel against Han, and the King of Qi rebelled against Han and allied with Chu. King Xiang himself marched east to strike Qi. He reached Chenyi where he heard that the King of Han had already occupied the three parts of Guanzhong and would attack Chu; King Xiang then returned to lead his troops north, killing Tian Rong. The King of Han went out to lead his troops to seize Pengcheng; King Xiang heard this and led his troops back to defeat the King of Han at Pengcheng, beheaded Marquis of Jiujiang, and the King of Han fled. King Xiang then went north to strike the lands of Qi; all of Qi revolted to follow Tian Rong's younger brother Tian Heng as king. The King of Han gained possession of Lu, Liang, Chu, and Zhao, and sent envoys respectfully inviting the kings of the feudal lords to attack Chu together. In the fourth month of the third year of Han, King Xiang heard that the King of Han had occupied Pengcheng; King Xiang was then in Qi, riding day and night from Qi, engaging the Han army at Lu. The Han army had many soldiers, tens of thousands of people, and blocked the water's edge; the King of Chu constantly selected elite cavalry of three thousand, the Han army was completely defeated. In the fourth month of that year, King Xiang went west through Lingbi, striking the troops of Han and the feudal lords, defeating them; Liang and Chu were pacified. The King of Han fled north, crossing the Sui River.

sentences.zh: 是時，漢還定三秦。

translations.text: He obtained the soldiers of Marquis of Jiangxia and the King of Han troops, garrisoned them at Yongqiu, planning together to strike Chu.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞漢王皆已并關中，且東，齊、趙叛之：大怒。

translations.text: Intending to go west to strike King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 乃以故吳令鄭昌為韓王，以距漢。

translations.text: King Xiang heard this and made camp at Lu, attacking eastward.

sentences.zh: 令蕭公角等擊彭越。

translations.text: Marquis of Jiangxia and the King of Han's troops saw King Xiang coming and fled.

sentences.zh: 彭越敗蕭公角等。

translations.text: King Xiang then gathered his troops together and went west from Xiao, striking the Han army at dawn and going east, reaching Pengcheng at midday, greatly defeating the Han army.

sentences.zh: 漢使張良徇韓，乃遺項王書曰：「漢王失職，欲得關中，如約即止，不敢東。」

translations.text: The Han army all fled, following each other into the Gu and Si rivers; over a hundred thousand Han troops were killed.

sentences.zh: 又以齊、梁反書遺項王曰：「齊欲與趙并滅楚。」

translations.text: The Han troops all fled south to the mountains; Chu pursued and struck them to east of Lingbi at the Sui River.

sentences.zh: 楚以此故無西意，而北擊齊。

translations.text: The Han army retreated and was pushed back by Chu; many were killed; over a hundred thousand Han troops all entered the Sui River, and the Sui River stopped flowing because of them.

sentences.zh: 徵兵九江王布。

translations.text: They surrounded the King of Han three times round.

sentences.zh: 布稱疾不往，使將將數千人行。

translations.text: Thereupon a great wind arose from the northwest, breaking trees and overturning houses, raising sand and stones, darkness descending at midday, striking head-on against the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 項王由此怨布也。

translations.text: The Chu army was thrown into great disorder and scattered, and the King of Han was then able to escape with several tens of riders; he wished to pass through Pei to collect his family and go west;

sentences.zh: 漢之二年冬，項羽遂北至城陽，田榮亦將兵會戰。

translations.text: but Chu also sent men to pursue them to Pei and take the King of Han's family—the family had all disappeared and did not meet the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 田榮不勝，走至平原，平原民殺之。

translations.text: On the road the King of Han happened to find Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan and then loaded them on his chariot.

sentences.zh: 遂北燒夷齊城郭室屋，皆阬田榮降卒，系虜其老弱婦女。

translations.text: Chu cavalry pursued the King of Han; the King of Han in his urgency pushed Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan off the chariot; Duke Teng constantly got down to pick them up and load them back.

sentences.zh: 徇齊至北海，多所殘滅。

translations.text: It was like this three times.

sentences.zh: 齊人相聚而叛之。

translations.text: He said: "Though urgent, we cannot drive fast—how can you abandon them?"

sentences.zh: 於是田榮弟田橫收齊亡卒得數萬人，反城陽。

translations.text: Thereupon they finally escaped.

sentences.zh: 項王因留，連戰未能下。

translations.text: Seeking the Grand Duke and Lü Hou, they did not meet.

He obtained the soldiers of Marquis of Jiangxia and the King of Han troops, garrisoned them at Yongqiu, planning together to strike Chu. Intending to go west to strike King Xiang. King Xiang heard this and made camp at Lu, attacking eastward. Marquis of Jiangxia and the King of Han's troops saw King Xiang coming and fled. King Xiang then gathered his troops together and went west from Xiao, striking the Han army at dawn and going east, reaching Pengcheng at midday, greatly defeating the Han army. The Han army all fled, following each other into the Gu and Si rivers; over a hundred thousand Han troops were killed. The Han troops all fled south to the mountains; Chu pursued and struck them to east of Lingbi at the Sui River. The Han army retreated and was pushed back by Chu; many were killed; over a hundred thousand Han troops all entered the Sui River, and the Sui River stopped flowing because of them. They surrounded the King of Han three times round. Thereupon a great wind arose from the northwest, breaking trees and overturning houses, raising sand and stones, darkness descending at midday, striking head-on against the Chu army. The Chu army was thrown into great disorder and scattered, and the King of Han was then able to escape with several tens of riders; he wished to pass through Pei to collect his family and go west; but Chu also sent men to pursue them to Pei and take the King of Han's family—the family had all disappeared and did not meet the King of Han. On the road the King of Han happened to find Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan and then loaded them on his chariot. Chu cavalry pursued the King of Han; the King of Han in his urgency pushed Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan off the chariot; Duke Teng constantly got down to pick them up and load them back. It was like this three times. He said: "Though urgent, we cannot drive fast—how can you abandon them?" Thereupon they finally escaped. Seeking the Grand Duke and Lü Hou, they did not meet.

sentences.zh: 春，漢王部五諸侯兵，凡五十六萬人，東伐楚。

translations.text: Shen Yiji followed the Grand Duke and Lü Hou traveling secretly, seeking the King of Han, but instead encountered the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 項王聞之，即令諸將擊齊，而自以精兵三萬人南從魯出胡陵。

translations.text: The Chu army then took them back and reported to King Xiang; King Xiang constantly kept them in the army.

sentences.zh: 四月，漢皆已入彭城，收其貨寶美人，日置酒高會。

translations.text: At this time Lü Hou's elder brother Lord Zhou Lü commanded Han troops stationed at Xiayi; the King of Han stole away to join him and gradually gathered his officers and troops.

sentences.zh: 項王乃西從蕭，晨擊漢軍而東，至彭城，日中，大破漢軍。

translations.text: Reaching Yingyang, all the defeated armies assembled; Xiao He also sent forth from Guanzhong the old and weak not yet registered, all arriving at Yingyang, and they greatly rallied again.

sentences.zh: 漢軍皆走，相隨入穀、泗水，殺漢卒十餘萬人。

translations.text: Chu arose from Pengcheng, constantly riding victory to pursue northward, and fought with Han between Jing and Suo south of Yingyang; Han defeated Chu, so Chu could not pass west of Yingyang.

sentences.zh: 漢卒皆南走山，楚又追擊至靈壁東睢水上。

translations.text: When King Xiang rescued Pengcheng and pursued the King of Han to Yingyang, Tian Heng also managed to recover Qi and installed Tian Rong's son Guang as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 漢軍卻，為楚所擠，多殺，漢卒十餘萬人皆入睢水，睢水為之不流。

translations.text: After the King of Han's defeat at Pengcheng, the feudal lords all again joined with Chu and turned their backs on Han.

sentences.zh: 圍漢王三匝。

translations.text: The Han army at Yingyang constructed a walled supply road connecting it to the river to obtain grain from Ao Granary.

sentences.zh: 於是大風從西北而起，折木發屋，揚沙石，窈冥晝晦，逢迎楚軍。

translations.text: In the third year of Han, King Xiang repeatedly raided and seized Han's supply road; the King of Han's food was scarce and he was afraid; he requested peace, offering to cede Yingyang and west as Han.

sentences.zh: 楚軍大亂，壞散，而漢王乃得與數十騎遁去，欲過沛，收家室而西；

translations.text: King Xiang wished to accept this.

sentences.zh: 楚亦使人追之沛，取漢王家：家皆亡，不與漢王相見。

translations.text: Marquis of Liyang Fan Zeng said: "Han is easy to deal with; now if you release them without taking them, you will certainly regret it later."

sentences.zh: 漢王道逢得孝惠、魯元，乃載行。

translations.text: King Xiang then urgently besieged Yingyang together with Fan Zeng.

sentences.zh: 楚騎追漢王，漢王急，推墮孝惠、魯元車下，滕公常下收載之。

translations.text: The King of Han was troubled by this and employed Chen Ping's stratagem to sow discord with King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 如是者三。

translations.text: When King Xiang's envoy came, they prepared a grand feast and were about to present it.

sentences.zh: 曰：「雖急不可以驅，柰何棄之？」

translations.text: Seeing the envoy, they feigned shock and said: "I thought it was the Second Father's envoy, but it turns out to be King Xiang's envoy."

sentences.zh: 於是遂得脫。

translations.text: They took it away and instead served poor food to King Xiang's envoy.

sentences.zh: 求太公、呂后不相遇。

translations.text: The envoy returned and reported to King Xiang; King Xiang then suspected Fan Zeng of having secret dealings with Han and gradually took away his authority.

sentences.zh: 審食其從太公、呂后閒行，求漢王，反遇楚軍。

translations.text: Fan Zeng was greatly enraged and said: "The affairs of all under Heaven are largely settled; may the king manage them yourself.

sentences.zh: 楚軍遂與歸，報項王，項王常置軍中。

translations.text: I request to be granted my aged bones to return to the ranks."

Shen Yiji followed the Grand Duke and Lü Hou traveling secretly, seeking the King of Han, but instead encountered the Chu army. The Chu army then took them back and reported to King Xiang; King Xiang constantly kept them in the army. At this time Lü Hou's elder brother Lord Zhou Lü commanded Han troops stationed at Xiayi; the King of Han stole away to join him and gradually gathered his officers and troops. Reaching Yingyang, all the defeated armies assembled; Xiao He also sent forth from Guanzhong the old and weak not yet registered, all arriving at Yingyang, and they greatly rallied again. Chu arose from Pengcheng, constantly riding victory to pursue northward, and fought with Han between Jing and Suo south of Yingyang; Han defeated Chu, so Chu could not pass west of Yingyang. When King Xiang rescued Pengcheng and pursued the King of Han to Yingyang, Tian Heng also managed to recover Qi and installed Tian Rong's son Guang as King of Qi. After the King of Han's defeat at Pengcheng, the feudal lords all again joined with Chu and turned their backs on Han. The Han army at Yingyang constructed a walled supply road connecting it to the river to obtain grain from Ao Granary. In the third year of Han, King Xiang repeatedly raided and seized Han's supply road; the King of Han's food was scarce and he was afraid; he requested peace, offering to cede Yingyang and west as Han. King Xiang wished to accept this. Marquis of Liyang Fan Zeng said: "Han is easy to deal with; now if you release them without taking them, you will certainly regret it later." King Xiang then urgently besieged Yingyang together with Fan Zeng. The King of Han was troubled by this and employed Chen Ping's stratagem to sow discord with King Xiang. When King Xiang's envoy came, they prepared a grand feast and were about to present it. Seeing the envoy, they feigned shock and said: "I thought it was the Second Father's envoy, but it turns out to be King Xiang's envoy." They took it away and instead served poor food to King Xiang's envoy. The envoy returned and reported to King Xiang; King Xiang then suspected Fan Zeng of having secret dealings with Han and gradually took away his authority. Fan Zeng was greatly enraged and said: "The affairs of all under Heaven are largely settled; may the king manage them yourself. I request to be granted my aged bones to return to the ranks."

sentences.zh: 是時呂后兄周呂侯為漢將兵居下邑，漢王閒往從之，稍稍收其士卒。

translations.text: King Xiang consented.

sentences.zh: 至滎陽，諸敗軍皆會，蕭何亦發關中老弱未傅悉詣滎陽，復大振。

translations.text: Before traveling to reach Pengcheng, an ulcer burst on his back and he died.

sentences.zh: 楚起於彭城，常乘勝逐北，與漢戰滎陽南京、索閒，漢敗楚，楚以故不能過滎陽而西。

translations.text: Han general Ji Xin persuaded the King of Han saying: "Affairs are already urgent; I request to deceive Chu by pretending to be the king so the king can steal away."

King Xiang consented. Before traveling to reach Pengcheng, an ulcer burst on his back and he died. Han general Ji Xin persuaded the King of Han saying: "Affairs are already urgent; I request to deceive Chu by pretending to be the king so the king can steal away."

sentences.zh: 項王之救彭城，追漢王至滎陽，田橫亦得收齊，立田榮子廣為齊王。

translations.text: Thereupon the King of Han sent out two thousand armored women by night from Yingyang's east gate; the Chu troops attacked them from four sides.

sentences.zh: 漢王之敗彭城，諸侯皆復與楚而背漢。

translations.text: Ji Xin rode in a yellow-canopied chariot with a left-side banner and said: "The city has run out of food; the King of Han surrenders."

sentences.zh: 漢軍滎陽，筑甬道屬之河，以取敖倉粟。

translations.text: The Chu army all shouted "Long live!"

sentences.zh: 漢之三年，項王數侵奪漢甬道，漢王食乏，恐，請和，割滎陽以西為漢。

translations.text: The King of Han also with several tens of riders went out the west gate of the city and fled to Chenggao.

Thereupon the King of Han sent out two thousand armored women by night from Yingyang's east gate; the Chu troops attacked them from four sides. Ji Xin rode in a yellow-canopied chariot with a left-side banner and said: "The city has run out of food; the King of Han surrenders." The Chu army all shouted "Long live!" The King of Han also with several tens of riders went out the west gate of the city and fled to Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 項王欲聽之。

translations.text: King Xiang saw Ji Xin and asked: "Where is the King of Han?"

sentences.zh: 歷陽侯范增曰：「漢易與耳，今釋弗取，後必悔之。」

translations.text: He said: "The King of Han has already left."

sentences.zh: 項王乃與范增急圍滎陽。

translations.text: King Xiang burned and killed Ji Xin.

sentences.zh: 漢王患之，乃用陳平計閒項王。

translations.text: The King of Han sent Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Duke Cong, and Wei Bao to defend Yingyang.

sentences.zh: 項王使者來，為太牢具，舉欲進之。

translations.text: Zhou Ke and Duke Cong plotted, saying: "A king who has rebelled against his state is difficult to defend a city with."

sentences.zh: 見使者，詳驚愕曰：「吾以為亞父使者，乃反項王使者。」

translations.text: They then together killed Wei Bao.

sentences.zh: 更持去，以惡食食項王使者。

translations.text: Chu took Yingyang city and captured Zhou Ke alive.

sentences.zh: 使者歸報項王，項王乃疑范增與漢有私，稍奪之權。

translations.text: King Xiang said to Zhou Ke: "Be my general; I will make you supreme general and enfeoff you with thirty thousand households."

sentences.zh: 范增大怒，曰：「天下事大定矣，君王自為之。

translations.text: Zhou Ke reviled him, saying: "If you do not quickly surrender to Han, Han will now capture you; you are no match for Han."

sentences.zh: 願賜骸骨歸卒伍。」

translations.text: King Xiang was enraged, boiled Zhou Ke, and also killed Duke Cong.

sentences.zh: 項王許之。

translations.text: When the King of Han left Yingyang, he fled south to Wan and Ye, obtained King Bu of Jiujiang, marched gathering troops, and again entered to defend Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 行未至彭城，疽發背而死。

translations.text: In the fourth year of Han, King Xiang advanced his troops to besiege Chenggao.

King Xiang saw Ji Xin and asked: "Where is the King of Han?" He said: "The King of Han has already left." King Xiang burned and killed Ji Xin. The King of Han sent Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Duke Cong, and Wei Bao to defend Yingyang. Zhou Ke and Duke Cong plotted, saying: "A king who has rebelled against his state is difficult to defend a city with." They then together killed Wei Bao. Chu took Yingyang city and captured Zhou Ke alive. King Xiang said to Zhou Ke: "Be my general; I will make you supreme general and enfeoff you with thirty thousand households." Zhou Ke reviled him, saying: "If you do not quickly surrender to Han, Han will now capture you; you are no match for Han." King Xiang was enraged, boiled Zhou Ke, and also killed Duke Cong. When the King of Han left Yingyang, he fled south to Wan and Ye, obtained King Bu of Jiujiang, marched gathering troops, and again entered to defend Chenggao. In the fourth year of Han, King Xiang advanced his troops to besiege Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 漢將紀信說漢王曰：「事已急矣，請為王誑楚為王，王可以閒出。」

translations.text: The King of Han escaped, alone with Duke Teng going out Chenggao's north gate, crossed the Yellow River, and fled to Xiuwu, joining with Zhang Er and Han Xin's army.

sentences.zh: 於是漢王夜出女子滎陽東門被甲二千人，楚兵四面擊之。

translations.text: The various generals gradually managed to exit Chenggao and follow the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 紀信乘黃屋車，傅左纛，曰：「城中食盡，漢王降。」

translations.text: Chu then took Chenggao and wished to go west.

sentences.zh: 楚軍皆呼萬歲。

translations.text: Han sent troops to resist them at Gong, preventing them from going west.

sentences.zh: 漢王亦與數十騎從城西門出，走成皋。

translations.text: At this time, Peng Yue crossed the Yellow River to strike Chu at Dong'e, killing Chu general Xue Gong.

sentences.zh: 項王見紀信，問：「漢王安在？」

translations.text: King Xiang then went east himself to strike Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 曰：「漢王已出矣。」

translations.text: The King of Han obtained the Marquis of Huaiyin's troops and wished to cross south of the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 項王燒殺紀信。

translations.text: Zheng Zhong persuaded the King of Han, who then stopped and encamped in Henei.

The King of Han escaped, alone with Duke Teng going out Chenggao's north gate, crossed the Yellow River, and fled to Xiuwu, joining with Zhang Er and Han Xin's army. The various generals gradually managed to exit Chenggao and follow the King of Han. Chu then took Chenggao and wished to go west. Han sent troops to resist them at Gong, preventing them from going west. At this time, Peng Yue crossed the Yellow River to strike Chu at Dong'e, killing Chu general Xue Gong. King Xiang then went east himself to strike Peng Yue. The King of Han obtained the Marquis of Huaiyin's troops and wished to cross south of the Yellow River. Zheng Zhong persuaded the King of Han, who then stopped and encamped in Henei.

sentences.zh: 漢王使御史大夫周苛、樅公、魏豹守滎陽。

translations.text: He sent Liu Jia to lead troops to assist Peng Yue and burn Chu's accumulated stores.

sentences.zh: 周苛、樅公謀曰：「反國之王，難與守城。」

translations.text: King Xiang struck and broke them to the east, driving off Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 乃共殺魏豹。

translations.text: The King of Han then led troops to cross the Yellow River, retook Chenggao, encamped at Guangwu, and relied on Ao Granary for food.

sentences.zh: 楚下滎陽城，生得周苛。

translations.text: Having pacified the Eastern Sea, King Xiang came west and with Han faced each other at Guangwu and encamped, confronting each other for several months.

sentences.zh: 項王謂周苛曰：「為我將，我以公為上將軍，封三萬戶。」

translations.text: At this time, Peng Yue repeatedly rebelled in the land of Liang, cutting off Chu's grain supply; King Xiang was troubled by this.

sentences.zh: 周苛罵曰：「若不趣降漢，漢今虜若，若非漢敵也。」

translations.text: He made a high chopping block, placed the Grand Duke on top of it, and told the King of Han: "If you do not quickly surrender, I will boil the Grand Duke."

sentences.zh: 項王怒，烹周苛，井殺樅公。

translations.text: The King of Han said: "I and Xiang Yu both faced north to receive orders from King Huai, saying 'We agreed to be brothers'; my old man is then your old man—if you must boil your old man, then I hope you will share with me a cup of the broth."

He sent Liu Jia to lead troops to assist Peng Yue and burn Chu's accumulated stores. King Xiang struck and broke them to the east, driving off Peng Yue. The King of Han then led troops to cross the Yellow River, retook Chenggao, encamped at Guangwu, and relied on Ao Granary for food. Having pacified the Eastern Sea, King Xiang came west and with Han faced each other at Guangwu and encamped, confronting each other for several months. At this time, Peng Yue repeatedly rebelled in the land of Liang, cutting off Chu's grain supply; King Xiang was troubled by this. He made a high chopping block, placed the Grand Duke on top of it, and told the King of Han: "If you do not quickly surrender, I will boil the Grand Duke." The King of Han said: "I and Xiang Yu both faced north to receive orders from King Huai, saying 'We agreed to be brothers'; my old man is then your old man—if you must boil your old man, then I hope you will share with me a cup of the broth."

sentences.zh: 漢王之出滎陽，南走宛、葉，得九江王布，行收兵，復入保成皋。

translations.text: King Xiang was enraged and wished to kill him.

sentences.zh: 漢之四年，項王進兵圍成皋。

translations.text: Xiang Bo said: "Affairs under Heaven cannot yet be known, and moreover one who strives for all under Heaven does not care for family; even if you kill him there is no benefit, only increasing disaster."

sentences.zh: 漢王逃，獨與滕公出成皋北門，渡河走修武，從張耳、韓信軍。

translations.text: King Xiang followed this.

sentences.zh: 諸將稍稍得出成皋，從漢王。

translations.text: Chu and Han long confronted each other without resolution; the able-bodied suffered from military service, the old and weak were exhausted transporting grain.

sentences.zh: 楚遂拔成皋，欲西。

translations.text: King Xiang said to the King of Han: "All under Heaven has been in chaos for several years solely because of us two; I wish to challenge the King of Han to single combat to determine victory or defeat; let us not needlessly cause the fathers and sons of all under Heaven's people to suffer."

sentences.zh: 漢使兵距之鞏，令其不得西。

translations.text: The King of Han laughed and declined, saying: "I would rather fight with wits than fight with strength."

King Xiang was enraged and wished to kill him. Xiang Bo said: "Affairs under Heaven cannot yet be known, and moreover one who strives for all under Heaven does not care for family; even if you kill him there is no benefit, only increasing disaster." King Xiang followed this. Chu and Han long confronted each other without resolution; the able-bodied suffered from military service, the old and weak were exhausted transporting grain. King Xiang said to the King of Han: "All under Heaven has been in chaos for several years solely because of us two; I wish to challenge the King of Han to single combat to determine victory or defeat; let us not needlessly cause the fathers and sons of all under Heaven's people to suffer." The King of Han laughed and declined, saying: "I would rather fight with wits than fight with strength."

sentences.zh: 是時，彭越渡河擊楚東阿，殺楚將軍薛公。

translations.text: King Xiang ordered a brave warrior to come out and challenge.

sentences.zh: 項王乃自東擊彭越。

translations.text: Han had a skilled horseback archer named Lou Fan; when Chu challenged to three bouts, Lou Fan always shot and killed them.

sentences.zh: 漢王得淮陰侯兵，欲渡河南。

translations.text: King Xiang was greatly enraged and personally donned armor and grasped his halberd to challenge.

sentences.zh: 鄭忠說漢王，乃止壁河內。

translations.text: Lou Fan wanted to shoot him, but King Xiang glared and shouted at him; Lou Fan's eyes dared not look and his hands dared not release; he then fled back inside the ramparts and dared not come out again.

sentences.zh: 使劉賈將兵佐彭越，燒楚積聚。

translations.text: The King of Han sent men to secretly inquire, and it turned out to be King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 項王東擊破之，走彭越。

translations.text: The King of Han was greatly shocked.

sentences.zh: 漢王則引兵渡河，復取成皋，軍廣武，就敖倉食。

translations.text: Thereupon King Xiang then went to face the King of Han between Guangwu and speak with him.

sentences.zh: 項王已定東海來，西，與漢俱臨廣武而軍，相守數月。

translations.text: The King of Han enumerated his crimes; King Xiang was enraged and wished to do battle.

King Xiang ordered a brave warrior to come out and challenge. Han had a skilled horseback archer named Lou Fan; when Chu challenged to three bouts, Lou Fan always shot and killed them. King Xiang was greatly enraged and personally donned armor and grasped his halberd to challenge. Lou Fan wanted to shoot him, but King Xiang glared and shouted at him; Lou Fan's eyes dared not look and his hands dared not release; he then fled back inside the ramparts and dared not come out again. The King of Han sent men to secretly inquire, and it turned out to be King Xiang. The King of Han was greatly shocked. Thereupon King Xiang then went to face the King of Han between Guangwu and speak with him. The King of Han enumerated his crimes; King Xiang was enraged and wished to do battle.

sentences.zh: 當此時，彭越數反梁地，絕楚糧食，項王患之。

translations.text: The King of Han would not listen; King Xiang shot with a hidden crossbow and hit the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 為高俎，置太公其上，告漢王曰：「今不急下，吾烹太公。」

translations.text: The King of Han, wounded, fled into Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「吾與項羽俱北面受命懷王，曰『約為兄弟』，吾翁即若翁，必欲烹而翁，則幸分我一桮羹。」

translations.text: King Xiang heard that the Marquis of Huaiyin had already taken the region north of the Yellow River, broken Qi and Zhao, and was about to strike Chu, so he sent Long Ju to strike him.

sentences.zh: 項王怒，欲殺之。

translations.text: The Marquis of Huaiyin engaged in battle; cavalry general Guan Ying struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and killed Long Ju.

sentences.zh: 項伯曰：「天下事未可知，且為天下者不顧家，雖殺之無益，只益禍耳。」

translations.text: Han Xin consequently made himself King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 項王從之。

translations.text: King Xiang heard that Long Ju's army was broken and was then afraid, sending Wu She of Xutai to persuade the Marquis of Huaiyin.

The King of Han would not listen; King Xiang shot with a hidden crossbow and hit the King of Han. The King of Han, wounded, fled into Chenggao. King Xiang heard that the Marquis of Huaiyin had already taken the region north of the Yellow River, broken Qi and Zhao, and was about to strike Chu, so he sent Long Ju to strike him. The Marquis of Huaiyin engaged in battle; cavalry general Guan Ying struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and killed Long Ju. Han Xin consequently made himself King of Qi. King Xiang heard that Long Ju's army was broken and was then afraid, sending Wu She of Xutai to persuade the Marquis of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 楚漢久相持未決，丁壯苦軍旅，老弱罷轉漕。

translations.text: The Marquis of Huaiyin would not listen.

sentences.zh: 項王謂漢王曰：「天下匈匈數歲者，徒以吾兩人耳，願與漢王挑戰決雌雄，毋徒苦天下之民父子為也。」

translations.text: At this time, Peng Yue rebelled again, took the land of Liang, and cut off Chu's grain supply.

sentences.zh: 漢王笑謝曰：「吾寧鬬智，不能鬬力。」

translations.text: King Xiang then said to Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu and others: "Carefully defend Chenggao; even if Han wishes to challenge to battle, be cautious not to engage in battle, and do not let them get east—that is all.

sentences.zh: 項王令壯士出挑戰。

translations.text: In fifteen days I will certainly execute Peng Yue, settle the land of Liang, and then return to join the generals."

sentences.zh: 漢有善騎射者樓煩，楚挑戰三合，樓煩輒射殺之。

translations.text: He then went east and marched to strike Chenliu and Waihuang.

sentences.zh: 項王大怒，乃自被甲持戟挑戰。

translations.text: Waihuang would not fall.

sentences.zh: 樓煩欲射之，項王瞋目叱之，樓煩目不敢視，手不敢發，遂走還入壁，不敢復出。

translations.text: After several days it surrendered; King Xiang was enraged and ordered all males aged fifteen and above to assemble east of the city, intending to bury them alive.

sentences.zh: 漢王使人閒問之，乃項王也。

translations.text: An attendant of the magistrate of Waihuang, a boy of thirteen years, went to persuade King Xiang, saying: "Peng Yue by force coerced Waihuang; Waihuang was afraid, so it surrendered temporarily, waiting for the great king.

sentences.zh: 漢王大驚。

translations.text: When the great king arrived, if you bury them all alive, how can the hundred clans have a heart to submit?

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃即漢王相與臨廣武閒而語。

translations.text: From here eastward, over ten cities in the land of Liang will all be afraid and none will be willing to surrender."

sentences.zh: 漢王數之，項王怒，欲一戰。

translations.text: King Xiang considered his words correct and pardoned those of Waihuang who were to be buried alive.

sentences.zh: 漢王不聽，項王伏弩射中漢王。

translations.text: Going east to Suiyang, hearing of this they all competed to surrender to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 漢王傷，走入成皋。

translations.text: Han indeed repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle, but the Chu army would not come out.

The Marquis of Huaiyin would not listen. At this time, Peng Yue rebelled again, took the land of Liang, and cut off Chu's grain supply. King Xiang then said to Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu and others: "Carefully defend Chenggao; even if Han wishes to challenge to battle, be cautious not to engage in battle, and do not let them get east—that is all. In fifteen days I will certainly execute Peng Yue, settle the land of Liang, and then return to join the generals." He then went east and marched to strike Chenliu and Waihuang. Waihuang would not fall. After several days it surrendered; King Xiang was enraged and ordered all males aged fifteen and above to assemble east of the city, intending to bury them alive. An attendant of the magistrate of Waihuang, a boy of thirteen years, went to persuade King Xiang, saying: "Peng Yue by force coerced Waihuang; Waihuang was afraid, so it surrendered temporarily, waiting for the great king. When the great king arrived, if you bury them all alive, how can the hundred clans have a heart to submit? From here eastward, over ten cities in the land of Liang will all be afraid and none will be willing to surrender." King Xiang considered his words correct and pardoned those of Waihuang who were to be buried alive. Going east to Suiyang, hearing of this they all competed to surrender to King Xiang. Han indeed repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle, but the Chu army would not come out.

sentences.zh: 項王聞淮陰侯已舉河北，破齊、趙，且欲擊楚，乃使龍且往擊之。

translations.text: He sent men to insult them; after five or six days, the Grand Marshal was enraged and crossed his troops over the Fan River.

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯與戰，騎將灌嬰擊之，大破楚軍，殺龍且。

translations.text: When half the officers and troops had crossed, Han struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and completely obtained all Chu's wealth and bribes.

sentences.zh: 韓信因自立為齊王。

translations.text: Grand Marshal Jiu, Chief Clerk Yi, and King Xin of Sai all slit their own throats at the Fan River.

sentences.zh: 項王聞龍且軍破，則恐，使盱臺人武涉往說淮陰侯。

translations.text: Grand Marshal Jiu had formerly been a prison clerk at Qi; Chief Clerk Xin had also formerly been a prison official at Liyang; both men had once shown kindness to Xiang Liang, which is why King Xiang trusted and employed them.

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯弗聽。

translations.text: At that time, King Xiang was at Suiyang; hearing that Marquis of Haichun's army was defeated, he led his troops back.

sentences.zh: 是時，彭越復反，下梁地，絕楚糧。

translations.text: The Han army was besieging Zhongli Mo east of Yingyang; when King Xiang arrived, the Han army feared Chu and all fled to dangerous terrain.

sentences.zh: 項王乃謂海春侯大司馬曹咎等曰：「謹守成皋，則漢欲挑戰，慎勿與戰，毋令得東而已。

translations.text: At this time, Han troops were numerous and food plentiful; King Xiang's troops were exhausted and food cut off.

sentences.zh: 我十五日必誅彭越，定梁地，復從將軍。」

translations.text: Han sent Lu Jia to persuade King Xiang to request the Grand Duke; King Xiang would not listen.

sentences.zh: 乃東，行擊陳留、外黃。

translations.text: The King of Han again sent Marquis Gong to persuade King Xiang; King Xiang then made an agreement with Han to divide all under Heaven in the middle: those west of the Hong Canal would be Han, those east of the Hong Canal would be Chu.

He sent men to insult them; after five or six days, the Grand Marshal was enraged and crossed his troops over the Fan River. When half the officers and troops had crossed, Han struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and completely obtained all Chu's wealth and bribes. Grand Marshal Jiu, Chief Clerk Yi, and King Xin of Sai all slit their own throats at the Fan River. Grand Marshal Jiu had formerly been a prison clerk at Qi; Chief Clerk Xin had also formerly been a prison official at Liyang; both men had once shown kindness to Xiang Liang, which is why King Xiang trusted and employed them. At that time, King Xiang was at Suiyang; hearing that Marquis of Haichun's army was defeated, he led his troops back. The Han army was besieging Zhongli Mo east of Yingyang; when King Xiang arrived, the Han army feared Chu and all fled to dangerous terrain. At this time, Han troops were numerous and food plentiful; King Xiang's troops were exhausted and food cut off. Han sent Lu Jia to persuade King Xiang to request the Grand Duke; King Xiang would not listen. The King of Han again sent Marquis Gong to persuade King Xiang; King Xiang then made an agreement with Han to divide all under Heaven in the middle: those west of the Hong Canal would be Han, those east of the Hong Canal would be Chu.

sentences.zh: 外黃不下。

translations.text: King Xiang agreed to this and immediately returned the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children.

sentences.zh: 數日，已降，項王怒，悉令男子年十五已上詣城東，欲阬之。

translations.text: The army all shouted "Long live!"

sentences.zh: 外黃令舍人兒年十三，往說項王曰：「彭越彊劫外黃，外黃恐，故且降，待大王。

translations.text: The King of Han then enfeoffed Marquis Gong as Lord of Pingguo.

sentences.zh: 大王至，又皆阬之，百姓豈有歸心？

translations.text: He hid and refused to be seen again.

sentences.zh: 從此以東，梁地十餘城皆恐，莫肯下矣。」

translations.text: He said: "This man is a skilled debater under Heaven; wherever he resides he topples states, hence he is titled Lord of Pingguo."

sentences.zh: 項王然其言，乃赦外黃當阬者。

translations.text: Having made the agreement, King Xiang led his troops away and returned eastward.

sentences.zh: 東至睢陽，聞之皆爭下項王。

translations.text: Han wished to return westward; Zhang Liang and Chen Ping persuaded him, saying: "Han possesses more than half of all under Heaven, and the feudal lords are all attached to it.

King Xiang agreed to this and immediately returned the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children. The army all shouted "Long live!" The King of Han then enfeoffed Marquis Gong as Lord of Pingguo. He hid and refused to be seen again. He said: "This man is a skilled debater under Heaven; wherever he resides he topples states, hence he is titled Lord of Pingguo." Having made the agreement, King Xiang led his troops away and returned eastward. Han wished to return westward; Zhang Liang and Chen Ping persuaded him, saying: "Han possesses more than half of all under Heaven, and the feudal lords are all attached to it.

sentences.zh: 漢果數挑楚軍戰，楚軍不出。

translations.text: Chu troops are exhausted and food finished; this is the time when Heaven destroys Chu—it would be better to take advantage of the opportunity and take them completely.

sentences.zh: 使人辱之，五六日，大司馬怒，渡兵汜水。

translations.text: Now if you release them without striking, this is what is called 'raising a tiger to bring trouble upon oneself.'"

sentences.zh: 士卒半渡，漢擊之，大破楚軍，盡得楚國貨賂。

translations.text: The King of Han listened to this.

sentences.zh: 大司馬咎、長史翳、塞王欣皆自剄汜水上。

translations.text: In the fifth year of Han, the King of Han pursued King Xiang to south of Yangxia, stopped his army, and made an appointment with the Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin and Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue to meet and strike the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 大司馬咎者，故蘄獄掾，長史欣亦故櫟陽獄吏，兩人嘗有德於項梁，是以項王信任之。

translations.text: Reaching Guling, Xin and Yue's troops did not meet.

sentences.zh: 當是時，項王在睢陽，聞海春侯軍敗，則引兵還。

translations.text: Chu struck the Han army and greatly broke them.

sentences.zh: 漢軍方圍鐘離眛於滎陽東，項王至，漢軍畏楚，盡走險阻。

translations.text: The King of Han again entered his ramparts, dug deep trenches, and defended himself.

Chu troops are exhausted and food finished; this is the time when Heaven destroys Chu—it would be better to take advantage of the opportunity and take them completely. Now if you release them without striking, this is what is called 'raising a tiger to bring trouble upon oneself.'" The King of Han listened to this. In the fifth year of Han, the King of Han pursued King Xiang to south of Yangxia, stopped his army, and made an appointment with the Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin and Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue to meet and strike the Chu army. Reaching Guling, Xin and Yue's troops did not meet. Chu struck the Han army and greatly broke them. The King of Han again entered his ramparts, dug deep trenches, and defended himself.

sentences.zh: 是時，漢兵盛食多，項王兵罷食絕。

translations.text: He said to Zhang Zifang: "The feudal lords do not follow the agreement—what should be done?"

sentences.zh: 漢遣陸賈說項王，請太公，項王弗聽。

translations.text: He replied: "The Chu troops are about to be broken, but Xin and Yue have not yet had territory divided to them; that they do not arrive is naturally proper.

sentences.zh: 漢王復使侯公往說項王，項王乃與漢約，中分天下，割鴻溝以西者為漢，鴻溝而東者為楚。

translations.text: If the king can share all under Heaven with them, now you can immediately summon them.

sentences.zh: 項王許之，即歸漢王父母妻子。

translations.text: If you cannot, affairs cannot yet be known.

sentences.zh: 軍皆呼萬歲。

translations.text: If the king can give everything from Chen east to the sea entirely to Han Xin;

sentences.zh: 漢王乃封侯公為平國君。

translations.text: and from Suiyang north to Gucheng to give to Peng Yue—have each fight for themselves, then Chu will be easy to defeat."

sentences.zh: 匿弗肯復見。

translations.text: The King of Han said: "Excellent."

sentences.zh: 曰：「此天下辯士，所居傾國，故號為平國君。」

translations.text: Thereupon he sent envoys to inform Han Xin and Peng Yue, saying: "Join forces to strike Chu.

sentences.zh: 項王已約，乃引兵解而東歸。

translations.text: When Chu is broken, from Chen east to the sea will be given to the King of Qi, and from Suiyang north to Gucheng to Prime Minister Peng."

He said to Zhang Zifang: "The feudal lords do not follow the agreement—what should be done?" He replied: "The Chu troops are about to be broken, but Xin and Yue have not yet had territory divided to them; that they do not arrive is naturally proper. If the king can share all under Heaven with them, now you can immediately summon them. If you cannot, affairs cannot yet be known. If the king can give everything from Chen east to the sea entirely to Han Xin; and from Suiyang north to Gucheng to give to Peng Yue—have each fight for themselves, then Chu will be easy to defeat." The King of Han said: "Excellent." Thereupon he sent envoys to inform Han Xin and Peng Yue, saying: "Join forces to strike Chu. When Chu is broken, from Chen east to the sea will be given to the King of Qi, and from Suiyang north to Gucheng to Prime Minister Peng."

sentences.zh: 漢欲西歸，張良、陳平說曰：「漢有天下太半，而諸侯皆附之。

translations.text: When the envoys arrived, Han Xin and Peng Yue both reported: "We request to advance troops now."

sentences.zh: 楚兵罷食盡，此天亡楚之時也，不如因其機而遂取之。

translations.text: Han Xin then came from Qi; Liu Jia's army came from Shouchun and marched together, massacred Chengfu, and reached Gaixia.

sentences.zh: 今釋弗擊，此所謂『養虎自遺患』也。」

translations.text: Grand Marshal Zhou Yin rebelled against Chu, using Shu to massacre Liu, raised the troops of Jiujiang, followed Liu Jia and Peng Yue, all met at Gaixia, and went to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 漢王聽之。

translations.text: King Xiang's army was encamped at Gaixia; troops were few and food exhausted; the Han army and feudal lords' troops surrounded them in several layers.

sentences.zh: 漢五年，漢王乃追項王至陽夏南，止軍，與淮陰侯韓信、建成侯彭越期會而擊楚軍。

translations.text: At night they heard the Han army singing Chu songs on all four sides; King Xiang was then greatly shocked and said: "Has Han already obtained all of Chu?

sentences.zh: 至固陵，而信、越之兵不會。

translations.text: Why are there so many Chu people!"

sentences.zh: 楚擊漢軍，大破之。

translations.text: King Xiang then rose at night and drank in his tent.

sentences.zh: 漢王復入壁，深塹而自守。

translations.text: There was a beautiful woman named Yu who was constantly favored and followed him;

sentences.zh: 謂張子房曰：「諸侯不從約，為之柰何？」

translations.text: a fine horse named Zhui that he constantly rode.

sentences.zh: 對曰：「楚兵且破，信、越未有分地，其不至固宜。

translations.text: Thereupon King Xiang was grieved and sang with passion, composing a poem himself, saying: "My strength pulled up mountains, my spirit covered the world; yet times are unfavorable and Zhui will not advance.

sentences.zh: 君王能與共分天下，今可立致也。

translations.text: When Zhui will not advance, what can be done? Yu, oh Yu, what shall I do with you!"

sentences.zh: 即不能，事未可知也。

translations.text: He sang several stanzas; the beautiful woman harmonized with him.

sentences.zh: 君王能自陳以東傅海，盡與韓信；

translations.text: King Xiang wept, tears streaming down; those around him all wept, none able to look up.

sentences.zh: 睢陽以北至穀城，以與彭越：使各自為戰，則楚易敗也。」

translations.text: Thereupon King Xiang mounted his horse and rode; over eight hundred brave warriors under his command rode following him, burst straight through the encirclement by night heading south, and galloped away.

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「善。」

translations.text: At dawn, the Han army realized this and ordered cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue him with five thousand cavalry.

sentences.zh: 於是乃發使者告韓信、彭越曰：「并力擊楚。

translations.text: King Xiang crossed the Huai; only about a hundred riders were able to follow.

sentences.zh: 楚破，自陳以東傅海與齊王，睢陽以北至穀城與彭相國。」

translations.text: King Xiang reached Yinling and lost his way; he asked an old farmer, who deceived him saying "Left."

sentences.zh: 使者至，韓信、彭越皆報曰：「請今進兵。」

translations.text: Going left, he then fell into a great marsh.

sentences.zh: 韓信乃從齊往，劉賈軍從壽春并行，屠城父，至垓下。

translations.text: Because of this Han caught up with him.

sentences.zh: 大司馬周殷叛楚，以舒屠六，舉九江兵，隨劉賈、彭越皆會垓下，詣項王。

translations.text: King Xiang then again led his troops eastward and reached Dongcheng with only twenty-eight riders.

When the envoys arrived, Han Xin and Peng Yue both reported: "We request to advance troops now." Han Xin then came from Qi; Liu Jia's army came from Shouchun and marched together, massacred Chengfu, and reached Gaixia. Grand Marshal Zhou Yin rebelled against Chu, using Shu to massacre Liu, raised the troops of Jiujiang, followed Liu Jia and Peng Yue, all met at Gaixia, and went to King Xiang. King Xiang's army was encamped at Gaixia; troops were few and food exhausted; the Han army and feudal lords' troops surrounded them in several layers. At night they heard the Han army singing Chu songs on all four sides; King Xiang was then greatly shocked and said: "Has Han already obtained all of Chu? Why are there so many Chu people!" King Xiang then rose at night and drank in his tent. There was a beautiful woman named Yu who was constantly favored and followed him; a fine horse named Zhui that he constantly rode. Thereupon King Xiang was grieved and sang with passion, composing a poem himself, saying: "My strength pulled up mountains, my spirit covered the world; yet times are unfavorable and Zhui will not advance. When Zhui will not advance, what can be done? Yu, oh Yu, what shall I do with you!" He sang several stanzas; the beautiful woman harmonized with him. King Xiang wept, tears streaming down; those around him all wept, none able to look up. Thereupon King Xiang mounted his horse and rode; over eight hundred brave warriors under his command rode following him, burst straight through the encirclement by night heading south, and galloped away. At dawn, the Han army realized this and ordered cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue him with five thousand cavalry. King Xiang crossed the Huai; only about a hundred riders were able to follow. King Xiang reached Yinling and lost his way; he asked an old farmer, who deceived him saying "Left." Going left, he then fell into a great marsh. Because of this Han caught up with him. King Xiang then again led his troops eastward and reached Dongcheng with only twenty-eight riders.

sentences.zh: 項王軍壁垓下，兵少食盡，漢軍及諸侯兵圍之數重。

translations.text: Han cavalry pursuing numbered several thousand men.

sentences.zh: 夜聞漢軍四面皆楚歌，項王乃大驚曰：「漢皆已得楚乎？

translations.text: King Xiang judged he could not escape.

sentences.zh: 是何楚人之多也！」

translations.text: He said to his riders: "I have raised troops until now for eight years; I have personally fought over seventy battles; those I faced were broken, those I struck submitted; I have never been defeated, and thus established hegemony over all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 項王則夜起，飲帳中。

translations.text: Yet now I am finally trapped here; this is Heaven destroying me, not any fault in my warfare.

sentences.zh: 有美人名虞，常幸從；

translations.text: Today I am certainly resolved to die; I wish to fight a swift battle for you lords, certainly winning three victories, breaking through the encirclement for you lords, beheading a general, cutting down a flag, to let you lords know that Heaven is destroying me, that it is not any fault in my warfare."

sentences.zh: 駿馬名騅，常騎之。

translations.text: He then divided his riders into four squads facing four directions.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃悲歌慨，自為詩曰：「力拔山兮氣蓋世，時不利兮騅不逝。

translations.text: The Han army surrounded them in several layers.

sentences.zh: 騅不逝兮可柰何，虞兮虞兮柰若何！」

translations.text: King Xiang said to his riders: "I will take that general for you."

sentences.zh: 歌數闋，美人和之。

translations.text: He ordered the four-sided cavalry to gallop down, making an appointment to meet at three places east of the mountain.

sentences.zh: 項王泣數行下，左右皆泣，莫能仰視。

translations.text: Thereupon King Xiang shouted loudly and galloped down; the Han army all scattered; he then beheaded one Han general.

Han cavalry pursuing numbered several thousand men. King Xiang judged he could not escape. He said to his riders: "I have raised troops until now for eight years; I have personally fought over seventy battles; those I faced were broken, those I struck submitted; I have never been defeated, and thus established hegemony over all under Heaven. Yet now I am finally trapped here; this is Heaven destroying me, not any fault in my warfare. Today I am certainly resolved to die; I wish to fight a swift battle for you lords, certainly winning three victories, breaking through the encirclement for you lords, beheading a general, cutting down a flag, to let you lords know that Heaven is destroying me, that it is not any fault in my warfare." He then divided his riders into four squads facing four directions. The Han army surrounded them in several layers. King Xiang said to his riders: "I will take that general for you." He ordered the four-sided cavalry to gallop down, making an appointment to meet at three places east of the mountain. Thereupon King Xiang shouted loudly and galloped down; the Han army all scattered; he then beheaded one Han general.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃上馬騎，麾下壯士騎從者八百餘人，直夜潰圍南出，馳走。

translations.text: At this time, Marquis of Chiquan was cavalry general pursuing King Xiang; King Xiang glared and shouted at him; Marquis of Chiquan's man and horse were both terrified and withdrew several li.

sentences.zh: 平明，漢軍乃覺之，令騎將灌嬰以五千騎追之。

translations.text: Meeting with his riders at three places.

sentences.zh: 項王渡淮，騎能屬者百餘人耳。

translations.text: The Han army did not know where King Xiang was, so they divided their army into three and surrounded them again.

sentences.zh: 項王至陰陵，迷失道，問一田父，田父紿曰「左」。

translations.text: King Xiang then galloped and again beheaded one Han commandant, killed several tens or hundreds of men, and again gathered his riders—only two riders were lost.

sentences.zh: 左，乃陷大澤中。

translations.text: He then said to his riders: "How was that?"

sentences.zh: 以故漢追及之。

translations.text: The riders all bowed and said: "As the great king said."

sentences.zh: 項王乃復引兵而東，至東城，乃有二十八騎。

translations.text: Thereupon King Xiang wished to cross the Wu River eastward.

sentences.zh: 漢騎追者數千人。

translations.text: The magistrate of Wu River Pavilion had his boat moored waiting and said to King Xiang: "Though the east of the Yangtze is small, its territory is a thousand li square with a population of several hundred thousand—it would also be enough to be king.

sentences.zh: 項王自度不得脫。

translations.text: I hope the great king will quickly cross.

sentences.zh: 謂其騎曰：「吾起兵至今八歲矣，身七十餘戰，所當者破，所擊者服，未嘗敗北，遂霸有天下。

translations.text: Now only I have a boat; when the Han army arrives, they will have no way to cross."

sentences.zh: 然今卒困於此，此天之亡我，非戰之罪也。

translations.text: King Xiang laughed and said: "Heaven is destroying me—why should I cross!

sentences.zh: 今日固決死，願為諸君快戰，必三勝之，為諸君潰圍，斬將，刈旗，令諸君知天亡我，非戰之罪也。」

translations.text: Moreover, I crossed the Yangtze westward with eight thousand sons and younger brothers from east of the Yangtze; now not one returns—even if the fathers and elder brothers east of the Yangtze take pity and make me king, with what face would I see them?

sentences.zh: 乃分其騎以為四隊，四向。

translations.text: Even if they say nothing, would I alone not feel ashamed in my heart?"

sentences.zh: 漢軍圍之數重。

translations.text: He then said to the pavilion magistrate: "I know you are a worthy man.

sentences.zh: 項王謂其騎曰：「吾為公取彼一將。」

translations.text: I have ridden this horse for five years; it met none that could match it and once traveled a thousand li in one day—I cannot bear to kill it; I give it to you as a gift."

sentences.zh: 令四面騎馳下，期山東為三處。

translations.text: He then ordered his riders to all dismount and fight on foot, wielding short weapons in close combat.

sentences.zh: 於是項王大呼馳下，漢軍皆披靡，遂斬漢一將。

translations.text: Ji alone killed several hundred Han troops.

sentences.zh: 是時，赤泉侯為騎將，追項王，項王瞋目而叱之，赤泉侯人馬俱驚，辟易數里與其騎會為三處。

translations.text: King Xiang's body also received over ten wounds.

sentences.zh: 漢軍不知項王所在，乃分軍為三，復圍之。

translations.text: Looking around he saw Han cavalry Major Lü Matong and said: "Are you not my old friend?"

sentences.zh: 項王乃馳，復斬漢一都尉，殺數十百人，復聚其騎，亡其兩騎耳。

translations.text: Matong faced him and pointed to Wang Yi, saying: "This is King Xiang."

sentences.zh: 乃謂其騎曰：「何如？」

translations.text: King Xiang then said: "I have heard Han is offering a thousand gold pieces and ten thousand households for my head; I will do you this kindness."

sentences.zh: 騎皆伏曰：「如大王言。」

translations.text: He then slit his own throat and died.

At this time, Marquis of Chiquan was cavalry general pursuing King Xiang; King Xiang glared and shouted at him; Marquis of Chiquan's man and horse were both terrified and withdrew several li. Meeting with his riders at three places. The Han army did not know where King Xiang was, so they divided their army into three and surrounded them again. King Xiang then galloped and again beheaded one Han commandant, killed several tens or hundreds of men, and again gathered his riders—only two riders were lost. He then said to his riders: "How was that?" The riders all bowed and said: "As the great king said." Thereupon King Xiang wished to cross the Wu River eastward. The magistrate of Wu River Pavilion had his boat moored waiting and said to King Xiang: "Though the east of the Yangtze is small, its territory is a thousand li square with a population of several hundred thousand—it would also be enough to be king. I hope the great king will quickly cross. Now only I have a boat; when the Han army arrives, they will have no way to cross." King Xiang laughed and said: "Heaven is destroying me—why should I cross! Moreover, I crossed the Yangtze westward with eight thousand sons and younger brothers from east of the Yangtze; now not one returns—even if the fathers and elder brothers east of the Yangtze take pity and make me king, with what face would I see them? Even if they say nothing, would I alone not feel ashamed in my heart?" He then said to the pavilion magistrate: "I know you are a worthy man. I have ridden this horse for five years; it met none that could match it and once traveled a thousand li in one day—I cannot bear to kill it; I give it to you as a gift." He then ordered his riders to all dismount and fight on foot, wielding short weapons in close combat. Ji alone killed several hundred Han troops. King Xiang's body also received over ten wounds. Looking around he saw Han cavalry Major Lü Matong and said: "Are you not my old friend?" Matong faced him and pointed to Wang Yi, saying: "This is King Xiang." King Xiang then said: "I have heard Han is offering a thousand gold pieces and ten thousand households for my head; I will do you this kindness." He then slit his own throat and died.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃欲東渡烏江。

translations.text: Wang Yi took his head; the remaining cavalry trampled each other competing for King Xiang's body; dozens killed each other.

sentences.zh: 烏江亭長檥船待，謂項王曰：「江東雖小，地方千里，眾數十萬人，亦足王也。

translations.text: The five men together assembled his body; all parts matched.

sentences.zh: 願大王急渡。

translations.text: Therefore they divided his territory into five: enfeoffed Lü Matong as Marquis of Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, enfeoffed Lü Sheng as Marquis of Nieyang.

sentences.zh: 今獨臣有船，漢軍至，無以渡。」

translations.text: After King Xiang died, all the lands of Chu surrendered to Han; only Lu would not submit.

sentences.zh: 項王笑曰：「天之亡我，我何渡為！

translations.text: Han then led all under Heaven's troops wishing to massacre it, but because they maintained ritual propriety and died loyal to their lord, they took King Xiang's head to show Lu; the fathers and elder brothers of Lu then surrendered.

sentences.zh: 且籍與江東子弟八千人渡江而西，今無一人還，縱江東父兄憐而王我，我何面目見之？

translations.text: At first, when King Huai of Chu first enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu, and when he died, Lu was the last to submit; therefore they buried King Xiang at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu.

sentences.zh: 縱彼不言，籍獨不愧於心乎？」

translations.text: The King of Han announced mourning for him, wept, and departed.

sentences.zh: 乃謂亭長曰：「吾知公長者。

translations.text: All the Xiang clan's branch relatives—the King of Han did not execute any.

sentences.zh: 吾騎此馬五歲，所當無敵，嘗一日行千里，不忍殺之，以賜公。」

translations.text: He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Marquis of Sheyang.

sentences.zh: 乃令騎皆下馬步行，持短兵接戰。

translations.text: Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, and Marquis of Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan; they were bestowed the surname Liu.

sentences.zh: 獨籍所殺漢軍數百人。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: I heard from Zhou Sheng who said "Shun's eyes had double pupils"; I also heard that Xiang Yu also had double pupils.

sentences.zh: 項王身亦被十餘創。

translations.text: Could Yu be his descendant?

sentences.zh: 顧見漢騎司馬呂馬童，曰：「若非吾故人乎？」

translations.text: How sudden was his rise!

sentences.zh: 馬童面之，指王翳曰：「此項王也。」

translations.text: When Qin lost its governance, Chen She first raised difficulties; heroes arose like a swarm of bees and competed together—their numbers cannot be counted.

sentences.zh: 項王乃曰：「吾聞漢購我頭千金，邑萬戶，吾為若德。」

translations.text: Yet Yu without even a foot or inch of territory, riding and rising from among the fields, in three years then led the five feudal lords to destroy Qin, divided and carved up all under Heaven, and enfeoffed kings and marquises; governance issued from Yu; he was titled "Hegemon-King"—though his position did not last, from ancient times until now there has never been such a case.

sentences.zh: 乃自刎而死。

translations.text: When Yu turned his back on Guanzhong and longed for Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and made himself king, resentment grew and the kings and marquises rebelled against him—this was difficult indeed.

sentences.zh: 王翳取其頭，餘騎相蹂踐爭項王，相殺者數十人。

translations.text: Boasting of his achievements and victories, flourishing his personal cleverness without following the ancients, thinking the hegemon-king's enterprise could be managed by conquering all under Heaven through force alone—in five years he finally lost his state; his body died at Dongcheng, yet still he did not awaken or blame himself—this was an error.

sentences.zh: 最其後，郎中騎楊喜，騎司馬呂馬童，郎中呂勝、楊武各得其一體。

translations.text: In the end, Gentleman Rider Yang Xi, Cavalry Major Lü Matong, Gentleman Lü Sheng, and Yang Wu each obtained one part of his body.

sentences.zh: 五人共會其體，皆是。

translations.text: The five men together assembled his body; all parts matched.

sentences.zh: 故分其地為五：封呂馬童為中水侯，封王翳為杜衍侯，封楊喜為赤泉侯，封楊武為吳防侯，封呂勝為涅陽侯。

translations.text: Therefore they divided his territory into five: enfeoffed Lü Matong as Marquis of Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, enfeoffed Lü Sheng as Marquis of Nieyang.

Wang Yi took his head; the remaining cavalry trampled each other competing for King Xiang's body; dozens killed each other. The five men together assembled his body; all parts matched. Therefore they divided his territory into five: enfeoffed Lü Matong as Marquis of Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, enfeoffed Lü Sheng as Marquis of Nieyang. After King Xiang died, all the lands of Chu surrendered to Han; only Lu would not submit. Han then led all under Heaven's troops wishing to massacre it, but because they maintained ritual propriety and died loyal to their lord, they took King Xiang's head to show Lu; the fathers and elder brothers of Lu then surrendered. At first, when King Huai of Chu first enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu, and when he died, Lu was the last to submit; therefore they buried King Xiang at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu. The King of Han announced mourning for him, wept, and departed. All the Xiang clan's branch relatives—the King of Han did not execute any. He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Marquis of Sheyang. Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, and Marquis of Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan; they were bestowed the surname Liu. The Grand Historian says: I heard from Zhou Sheng who said "Shun's eyes had double pupils"; I also heard that Xiang Yu also had double pupils. Could Yu be his descendant? How sudden was his rise! When Qin lost its governance, Chen She first raised difficulties; heroes arose like a swarm of bees and competed together—their numbers cannot be counted. Yet Yu without even a foot or inch of territory, riding and rising from among the fields, in three years then led the five feudal lords to destroy Qin, divided and carved up all under Heaven, and enfeoffed kings and marquises; governance issued from Yu; he was titled "Hegemon-King"—though his position did not last, from ancient times until now there has never been such a case. When Yu turned his back on Guanzhong and longed for Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and made himself king, resentment grew and the kings and marquises rebelled against him—this was difficult indeed. Boasting of his achievements and victories, flourishing his personal cleverness without following the ancients, thinking the hegemon-king's enterprise could be managed by conquering all under Heaven through force alone—in five years he finally lost his state; his body died at Dongcheng, yet still he did not awaken or blame himself—this was an error. In the end, Gentleman Rider Yang Xi, Cavalry Major Lü Matong, Gentleman Lü Sheng, and Yang Wu each obtained one part of his body. The five men together assembled his body; all parts matched. Therefore they divided his territory into five: enfeoffed Lü Matong as Marquis of Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, enfeoffed Lü Sheng as Marquis of Nieyang.

sentences.zh: 項王已死，楚地皆降漢，獨魯不下。

translations.text: After King Xiang died, all the lands of Chu surrendered to Han; only Lu would not submit.

sentences.zh: 漢乃引天下兵欲屠之，為其守禮義，為主死節，乃持項王頭視魯，魯父兄乃降。

translations.text: Han then led all under Heaven's troops wishing to massacre it, but because they maintained ritual propriety and died loyal to their lord, they took King Xiang's head to show Lu; the fathers and elder brothers of Lu then surrendered.

sentences.zh: 始，楚懷王初封項籍為魯公，及其死，魯最後下，故以魯公禮葬項王穀城。

translations.text: At first, when King Huai of Chu first enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu, and when he died, Lu was the last to submit; therefore they buried King Xiang at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu.

sentences.zh: 漢王為發哀，泣之而去。

translations.text: The King of Han announced mourning for him, wept, and departed.

After King Xiang died, all the lands of Chu surrendered to Han; only Lu would not submit. Han then led all under Heaven's troops wishing to massacre it, but because they maintained ritual propriety and died loyal to their lord, they took King Xiang's head to show Lu; the fathers and elder brothers of Lu then surrendered. At first, when King Huai of Chu first enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu, and when he died, Lu was the last to submit; therefore they buried King Xiang at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu. The King of Han announced mourning for him, wept, and departed.

sentences.zh: 諸項氏枝屬，漢王皆不誅。

translations.text: All the Xiang clan's branch relatives—the King of Han did not execute any.

sentences.zh: 乃封項伯為射陽侯。

translations.text: He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Marquis of Sheyang.

sentences.zh: 桃侯、平皋侯、玄武侯皆項氏，賜姓劉。

translations.text: Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, and Marquis of Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan; they were bestowed the surname Liu.

All the Xiang clan's branch relatives—the King of Han did not execute any. He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Marquis of Sheyang. Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, and Marquis of Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan; they were bestowed the surname Liu.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：吾聞之周生曰「舜目蓋重瞳子」，又聞項羽亦重瞳子。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: I heard from Zhou Sheng who said "Shun's eyes had double pupils"; I also heard that Xiang Yu also had double pupils.

sentences.zh: 羽豈其苗裔邪？

translations.text: Could Yu be his descendant?

sentences.zh: 何興之暴也！

translations.text: How sudden was his rise!

sentences.zh: 夫秦失其政，陳涉首難，豪傑蜂起，相與并爭，不可勝數。

translations.text: When Qin lost its governance, Chen She first raised difficulties; heroes arose like a swarm of bees and competed together—their numbers cannot be counted.

sentences.zh: 然羽非有尺寸，乘執起隴畝之中，三年，遂將五諸侯滅秦，分裂天下，而封王侯，政由羽出，號為「霸王」，位雖不終，近古以來未嘗有也。

translations.text: Yet Yu without even a foot or inch of territory, riding and rising from among the fields, in three years then led the five feudal lords to destroy Qin, divided and carved up all under Heaven, and enfeoffed kings and marquises; governance issued from Yu; he was titled "Hegemon-King"—though his position did not last, from ancient times until now there has never been such a case.

sentences.zh: 及羽背關懷楚，放逐義帝而自立，怨王侯叛己，難矣。

translations.text: When Yu turned his back on Guanzhong and longed for Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and made himself king, resentment grew and the kings and marquises rebelled against him—this was difficult indeed.

sentences.zh: 自矜功伐，奮其私智而不師古，謂霸王之業，欲以力征經營天下，五年卒亡其國，身死東城，尚不覺寤而不自責，過矣。

translations.text: Boasting of his achievements and victories, flourishing his personal cleverness without following the ancients, thinking the hegemon-king's enterprise could be managed by conquering all under Heaven through force alone—in five years he finally lost his state; his body died at Dongcheng, yet still he did not awaken or blame himself—this was an error.

sentences.zh: 乃引「天亡我，非用兵之罪也」，豈不謬哉！

translations.text: To then say "Heaven destroyed me, it was not any fault in my use of troops"—is this not absurd!

The Grand Historian says: I heard from Zhou Sheng who said "Shun's eyes had double pupils"; I also heard that Xiang Yu also had double pupils. Could Yu be his descendant? How sudden was his rise! When Qin lost its governance, Chen She first raised difficulties; heroes arose like a swarm of bees and competed together—their numbers cannot be counted. Yet Yu without even a foot or inch of territory, riding and rising from among the fields, in three years then led the five feudal lords to destroy Qin, divided and carved up all under Heaven, and enfeoffed kings and marquises; governance issued from Yu; he was titled "Hegemon-King"—though his position did not last, from ancient times until now there has never been such a case. When Yu turned his back on Guanzhong and longed for Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and made himself king, resentment grew and the kings and marquises rebelled against him—this was difficult indeed. Boasting of his achievements and victories, flourishing his personal cleverness without following the ancients, thinking the hegemon-king's enterprise could be managed by conquering all under Heaven through force alone—in five years he finally lost his state; his body died at Dongcheng, yet still he did not awaken or blame himself—this was an error. To then say "Heaven destroyed me, it was not any fault in my use of troops"—is this not absurd!
